story:
“It’s a quiet poem, a light choreography a seance.
It’s a man, in a blue shirt, waving his arms about, a dance.
It’s a phrase, a refrain, a language.
It’s a magic trick.”

 

In Burrows is an act of speaking and listening, of moving and pausing, always burrowing. Shifting between poetry, movement and prayer, In Burrows is an act of faith - a slow fall into the gaps between words, hoping to find something worth landing on.

 

About In Burrows


In Burrows is a performance by Andy Edwards exploring themes of language and communication, considering how we engage with the world around us. Using the act of improvised description, framed through a sequence of choreographies, In Burrows is open to perception - it questions what can be verbalised and what can't, and asks how we communicate the incommunicable. The performance will be presented at Glasgow's Tron Theatre over the two nights of March 23rd & 24th 2018.

In Burrows was developed with support from Tron Theatre and is currently supported by Glasgow Connected Arts Network (GCAN) and WASPS Artists’ Studios. With GCAN's generous contribution to our budget, Andy has enlisted the talents of BSL-fluent artist and interpreter Amy Cheskin, to develop a visual language for the work, which can engage audiences with a diverse range of experiences and abilities, with particular interest in those who are D/deaf or hard-of-hearing.  

The opportunity to perform at Tron Theatre is one we are thrilled to seize, and whilst we have our foot in the door, we'd like to bring some friends in with us too. As well as presenting In Burrows over two nights, we will also be inviting two local artists to perform short works responding to similar themes, of around 10 minutes in length. These artists will receive the opportunity to perform on both nights of the run. They will also receive support from the In Burrows team, production and technical support and a performance fee. An open call closing January 31st extends an invitation for applications to perform, and we are excited to offer two artists the chance to perform with us in one of Glasgow's leading theatres.

The contributions we have secured serve to support the development of the work, and measures necessary to make it accessible to a range of audiences. However, there are still a number of costs associated with presenting a work in a theatre like the Tron, and it is for these costs which we invite your support and donation. 

Through flexible funding, we hope to raise a total of £1400 to cover remaining production costs. We have broken down this amount into milestones below, to make transparent the costs we seek to cover, how we have prioritised these costs, and how your donation will support the project:
 

Target Bandings


If we raise:                  We can:

£250                            Pay two guest performers over two nights.

£400                            Cover costs of necessary insurance to cover all artists.

£500                            Offer each performer a materials fee, and cover our print marketing costs.

£700                            Pay a lighting designer to curate lighting for the In Burrows event.

£850                            Pay a sound designer to compose music for the In Burrows event.

£950                            Cover additional production costs; pre-rig/materials.

£1100                          Pay a stage manager over two nights.

£1200                          Pay In Burrows performers over two nights.

£1400                          Cover the cost/fulfillment of rewards without deducting from our budget.

 

If you are unable to donate to the project, we would appreciate your help in sharing the fundraiser on your social feeds, and spreading the word to your friends and family.

We thank you for you for your support, in whatever capacity you can offer, and we hope to see you at one of the performances.

 

In Burrows Creative Team


Created by Andy Edwards
Dramaturgy by Paul Hughes
Produced by Cairan McLaggan
Developed with Carrie Skinner and Amy Cheskin

Performing March 23rd & 24th at Tron Theatre, Glasgow.

Tickets can be booked now from: https://www.tron.co.uk/event/in-burrows/
Follow the project: http://inburrows.tumblr.com
Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/events/2004280153190103/

story:
Video Promo Material from Simon Fox (BBC The Social) and Katie Stephen (Puppet Animation Scotland, Manipulate Fest 2018)

Music by Glassmasterer (Vic Galloway's Top 25 Artist's to look out for this year)

Jessica is currently working with Surge Physical Theatre in Mother's Ruin at Solas Festival, Dundee Festival, and Surge Festival.

Jessica spoke to The List's Editor Gareth Vile; http://vilearts.blogspot.com/2018/01/dramaturgi...

THE PROJECT

A Research and Development project over 4 months exploring the impact Social Media has on young people’s mental health. Funding will allow meaningful creative collaboration with young people. 

STYLE OF PERFORMANCE

The aim is to create a 40-minute production using Shadow Theatre, Silhouette Animation and Puppetry followed by 15-20 minutes of interactive play, where the audience are invited behind the screen to play with lights and puppets. 

It is expected that strong visuals and performance sketches that utilise the young people’s skills in animation and digital design will be created that define some of the most pertinent facts about online safety and self-care from the perspective of 12-16yr olds. They will be involved in the storyline, visuals, and developing the most exciting form of staging for that audience. Such activities promote the development of skills in areas such as talking and working with others, and contribute greatly to children and young people’s mental, emotional, social and physical wellbeing.

THE AUDIENCE

There is a renewed focus for theatre for young people, especially as this year, 2018, is Year of the Young People by Creative Scotland. Jessica is creating a show aimed at adolescents in line with this new and essential focus.

The production will be designed and developed to be highly accessible. The story will be told visually through performers, puppets, and animations. There is no spoken dialogue but some use of text which can be translated for all languages, and therefore accessible for deaf audiences. Jessica Innes and Lewis Maxwell Bigham (Glassmasterer Music) are collaborating on a soundtrack for the piece.

RELEVANCE

Research supported how important this issue is for young people; 

"Self-harm among young teenage girls rose nearly 70 per cent after 2011, due partly to “extreme” obsession with social media compared to boys, a new study has found."

https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/18/heartbreaking-rise-self-harm-among-young-teenage-girls/

"Children as young as nine have contacted the NSPCC’s Childline complaining of being tormented by name-calling, blackmail and death threats posted publicly on social media profiles and blogs."

https://www.theguardian.com/society/2017/nov/13/counselling-for-cyberbullying-has-doubled-in-five-years-childrens-charity

“It’s becoming more and more obvious how the pressures of social media disproportionately affect teenage girls. I can see it all around me. Pressure to be perfect. To look perfect, act perfect, have the perfect body, have the perfect group of friends, the perfect amount of likes on Instagram. … And if you don’t meet these ridiculously high standards, then the self-loathing and bullying begins.”

https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/sep/16/social-media-mental-health-teenagers-government-pshe-lessons

""We had a class discussion about Facebook and every single one of the students said their parents spend more time on Facebook than they do talking to their child. It was very eye opening for me," commented Abbey Fauntleroy."

"However, one mum pointed out that her teenagers were just as bad, often choosing their phone over family time."

"I hate my mum's phone and I wish she never had one," is what one primary school child wrote in a class assignment.

http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-trending-44224319

"A former Facebook executive has said he feels “tremendous guilt” over his work on “tools that are ripping apart the social fabric of how society works” 

https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/dec...

 

HOW SOCIAL MEDIA CAN AFFECT SCHOOL – PARENTS ARE UNAWARE.

Conversations with young people at The Zoom Club at Summerhall focused on how they cope when people post nasty comments about them and their friends online. They gave examples of pranks that have gone too far - a student made a fake account of one of their teachers on Twitter and posted made up gossip from the staff room. 

Many said they'd love more spaces in Edinburgh where they can "sit down and talk" away from mobile phones. They said they enjoyed speaking face to face with people from other age groups, however "you are made fun of if you have a friend in the year below". One said, "some people in my school are bullied because they're not on social media, but one was bullied because of her youtube channel".  One said that they are "excluded from every group chat" in their year group, and feel isolated. One said their main purpose for Social Media is playing games, but people get very aggressive and use a lot of swear words. One said that it upsets them how much racism, homophobia, transphobia, and more is posted online in the comment sections. 

They all said they could not speak to their parents about Social Media - a mix of "they don't understand it" and "it's not a big deal to them - my gran uses it to send me pictures of cats". 

RESPONSE TO THE DEVELOPMENT SHOWN AT THE TRAVERSE THEATRE AS PART OF THE MANIPULATE FESTIVAL 2018.

"It was very intense with it feeling fast paced it felt like a symbol of anxiety"

"I found it amazing, probably because it’s so relatable – pushing a common experience to an extreme, ridiculous limit."

"It was very effective in capturing the anxiety and inertia mobile phones can enkindle" 

"The showing of the disconnect, the corrosion of social relationships comes across well. Love the simplicity and effectiveness of the shadow puppetry. Accessible for all." 

"Engaging and built anxiety, felt like it was making it approachable"

"Depressing and scared. I have an 11 year old"

"Sad that it has to be aimed at 12-16 year olds but it should be in today's society. Very thought provoking and well done."

"I never considered the impact that social media has on school, and this piece really did a good job showing that"


A compilation of scenes from a longer development entitled Behind The Screen, looks at the effects social media on female tweens and teens, directed by director and main performer, Jessica Innes. Accessible for all, not just in content but also in form, as this piece is presented with shadow puppetry, shadow theatre, and overhead projections in lieu of dialogue. Topical, especially in the era of Black Mirror-esque social critique, this piece looks at the themes of social disconnection, cyber-bullying, self esteem and body dysmorphia, and the dangerously ill effects of social media and the internet upon mental health, especially in today’s youth. Soundtrack by Glassmasterer (aka Lewis Maxwell Bigham) with complex, busy guitar melody, adds to the intensity of this piece. A moving and important production that will only increase in importance as we continue to educate ourselves and the next generations on how to stay mentally safe online.

- Edinburgh Guide.

WHAT YOUR HELP MEANS

Your contributions will allow Jessica to provide more Puppet making materials for the young people, and Lighting Sources to be used as part of the development process in workshops and sharings. This will give the young people the best opportunity to create and show their own stories. 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN SUPPORT

Please spread the word about Behind The Screen. This page will be monitored by a young person. By having a young person at the forefront of the project promoting the visuals made by other young people, it strengthens their voice in Scottish Theatre. This also encourages using Social Media safely and maturely; using Social Media as a tool for projects with allocated time, avoiding unnecessary addictive Social Media use.

https://www.facebook.com/behindthescreenplay/

Stay in touch! email hello@jessicainnes.co.uk

story:
“Phenomenal.. Theatre Re creates an entrancing, poignant world and an hour spent in it seems all too brief.” 

Edinburgh Spotlight on Blind Man’s Song

The Company

Established in 2009, Theatre Re is a critically acclaimed London-based international ensemble creating vibrant and emotional work on the edge of mime and theatre. Its productions have toured nationally and internationally following sell-out successes at the London International Mime Festival, Latitude and the Edinburgh Fringe.

www.retheatre.com | @TheatreRe | facebook.com/retheatre

Support So Far

Funded by Arts Council England

Co-commissioned by the London International Mime Festival and South Hill Park Arts Centre

Supported by Shoreditch Town Hall, Jacksons Lane, The Point Easleigh, The Lincoln Drill Hall and Haringey Council.

What we want to do:

« We all know that something is eternal. And it ain’t houses and it ain’t names, and it ain’t earth, and it ain’t even the stars... Everybody knows in their bones that something is eternal, and that something has to do with human beings... There is something, way down deep that’s eternal about every human being... And that’s what’s left when memory is gone. »

This quote from Thornton Wilder’s Our Town alludes to what we want to portray through The Nature of Forgetting (working title).

To forget means to be unable to remember. It implies the loss of accessibility to a memory, however it does not necessarily mean that the information is lost. Through the portrayal of one man’s inability to recollect his life, and building on recent neurobiological discoveries and interviews, we are developing a visually stunning, moving and intimate piece of theatre about what is left when memory is gone.

Following an initial four-week rehearsal period across December 2015 and February 2016 in London at Shoredicth Town Hall and at St Ann’s Library, The Nature of Forgetting (working title) will be developed for another 3 weeks at Saint Ann’s Library (London), Lincoln Drill Hall (Lincoln) and South Hill Park Arts Centre (Bracknell) in June and July 2016.

Two work-in-progress showcases will be organized at Lincoln Drill Hall on June 29th and at South Hill Park Arts Centre on July 7th. We will also be organizing free work-in-progress showings throughout the month of June (see our website for more information). 

How we are working:

Neuroscience research and understandings on memory and amnesia form the basis and foundation of our explorations. We are also interviewing older members of the community as well as people with dementia to create links between the research and real human experiences.

Rather than focusing on one person’s real story, we are fusing together multiple facts, narrative and non-narrative elements. It is from their connections and interactions that an intimate, powerful and visceral piece will emerge.

This work is supported by Jacksons Lane’s participation department, Haringey Council, the Alzheimer’s Society, the Haringey Memory Service, HAIL Mental Health Support Association, Haringey Older People’s Forum and University College London.

What We Need

Now that we have established links with supporters of the project, developed a timeline, appointed a strong team and started the devising process, we are seeking a little help from you to complete our budget.

Donations will contribute towards the costs of costumes, props, set, transportation and artistic fees.

Other Ways You Can Help

Another way to support the company is to come and see our work! Beyond that, if you are able and willing please help us to promote our shows through word of mouth, Facebook, Twitter and any other way you can possibly think of!

The Creative Team

Conceived & Directed by Guillaume Pigé

Devised and designed by the company

Performers & Musicians - Malik Ibheis, Chris Jones, Alex Judd, Guillaume Pigé, Eyglo Thorgeirsdottir, Andres Velasquez, Louise Wilcox

Original Music - Alex Judd

Lighting Designer - Katherine Graham

Costume & Props Designer - Malik Ibheis

Text - Sabrina Mahfouz

Dramaturge - A.C Smith

Scientific Collaborator - Professor Kate Jeffery

External Curator - Andrew Visnevski

External Advisor - Nuala Kiely (of the Mental Health Support Association in Tottenham)

story:
This is the show I've been waiting my whole life to make.

For me, Tourette's Syndrome has been the elephant in every room I've ever entered.  When I was diagnosed with this neurological disorder at age 7, I would tic on the subway and immediately search the car to see if anyone noticed.  In a school assembly, try as I always did to stifle it, I would be the pimply kid behind the repetitive bird calls.  As an adult, I often shove a scarf in my mouth at the theater to avoid disturbing the actors with my swine flu-like coughs.  Tourette's is hard to ignore.

So I've decided to stop trying!  I'm embracing it, and I've made an entire solo show about it!  My brilliant collaborator, Kel Haney, and I have spent MONTHS working on  what we believe will be an exciting and incredibly original new one-man theater piece.

This past spring, we were chosen by the legendary theater company, Mabou Mines, to take part in their residency and create something about Tourette's.  I then went to the Tourette Syndrome Association National Conference in Washington, DC (as a delegate from the NYC chapter) and got my mind blown.  To be in massive banquet halls with hundreds of kids and adults ticcing away was a cathartic experience to say the least.  Watching a girl periodically smack her father in the leg as he sat patiently and took it was unreal.  Listening as a smart young woman echoed speakers from the CDC- "basal basal basal, I'm so basal ganglia!  I can't help it!"- was hilarious.  Helping a man coax his son out of his full body tic of uncontrollably bear hugging another boy was exhilarating.  And watching groups of teens laugh and converse, relieved that they finally belonged, was beautiful.  

Kel and I have created a show about this week-long conference, tying in my own entertaining life experiences with Tourette's, and using an erratic and physical theater style (a nod to TS itself) and we are thrilled to be opening the season at La Mama , the legendary East Village theater.

We have come so far to be at this point, and we want this show to be spectacular. That's where you come in.  

We have hired a wonderfully talented creative team

Kel Haney- The show's co-creator and director, and my long-time collaborator.

Lighting Designer- Daisy Long, who did an amazing job on my last solo show, YOU'RE NOT TOUGH.  

Sound Designer- Elisheba Ittoop, who also did outstanding work on YOU'RE NOT TOUGH.

Costume Design- Summer Lee Jack

Scenic Design- Caite Hevner Kemp

Assistant Director- Nora Ives

Stage Manager- Jacqueline Filer


I strongly believe in paying artists for their hard work, and we couldn't produce this show the way it's meant to be without hiring the best people for the job.

Other costs we have are marketing, photography, videography, technical assistants, costume pieces, scenic pieces, lighting equipment...

We need to raise $6000

I'm so blessed to have such a talented and hard working team to create this show.  But I need your help.

In all my years working with special needs children, I have seen enormous growth when they are encouraged to be themselves and find their talents.  I have also, sadly, watched as many are discouraged and forced to conform to be something they aren't, leading to very depressing outcomes.  I was incredibly fortunate to be encouraged to thrive, and never to be ashamed of Tourette's.  This show demonstrates the power of following your dreams despite enormous challenges and my biggest hope is that other young people with Tourette's can see it and be inspired.

My friends at the Tourette Syndrome Association will be bringing groups of young people to our performances and we want to show them the power of theater.  
Proper production and design is imperative to that goal.

This is your chance to take part in something meaningful and important.

Donations of all sizes are appreciated.

    I'm so excited to share my story with you!

story:
Can you imagine? One day, when you open up your eyes and the world is overwhelmed by plastics?

 

Who are We

( from left to right: Goo Zhuan Xuan, Ch'ng Yee Von, Low Zhi Kai, Tan Lay Heong )

We are a group of four young Malaysia theatre practitioners. All of us have a strong interest in making our living space a more environment-friendly place. We are from different backgrounds: Visual Arts, Theatre and Puppetry but were connected by our passions and interests in shadow and the environment.

 

What is Plastic City

Plastic City is a Contemporary Shadow Puppetry Performance.

It depicts issue of the overwhelming amount of disposable plastic products in our world. We all know that plastic currently is a non degradable material (or yes but the cost is extremely expensive). But the humungous number of the usage of disposable plastic products is yet astonishing. Have you ever imagined that where would these used disposable plastic go? 

We support and advocate the idea of upcycling - reuse of resources. All materials that we used in the process of rehearsals are collected from what others have thrown away. In a world where resources are facing a serious problem of shortage, we should start from ourselves by extending the life of used objects.

 

What is TTTIFA

We have got an invitation to join an independent art festival in Taipei, Taiwan named -- Tua-Tiu-Tian International Festival of Arts (TTTIFA). 

TTTIFA is an independent art festival initiated by local Tua-Tiu-Tian entrepreneurs Bookstore 1920s, Thinkers’ Theatre (Che Zhi Theatre), and Chiang Wei-shui’Cultural Foundation. TTTIFA focuses on cross-era, cross-field, cross-nation, cross-culture, and even cross-language performances integrating innovative performing styles with local history, using the TTT’s historical buildings as the venue to develop local creations. Allowing artists from around the world to interact within TTT street houses, making them a talent interaction platform.

for more info: http://tttifa.com

 

What We Need

TTTIFA is an independent festival where all supports are coming from the ​grassroot:  local cultural organizations and independent societies. Therefore, we need to cover our own expenses which included flight, accommodation, local transportation allowance and travel insurance of the trip.

We have set a goal of $ 1700 which is enough for us to cover what is essential for the trip. These are:
$ 1000 - Return Flight x 4 person​
$ 600   - Accommodation (10 nights x 4 person)
$ 100   - Travel Insurance + Local Transportation Allowance (10 days x 4 person)

Below is our itinerary of the trip for your information:
October
23            -  Flight arrival at Taipei, Taiwan
24 - 26   -  Bump In / Set Up
27            -  Preview Night (for media, volunteers & supporters )
28 - 30   -  5 Shows
31             -  Bump Out & Dinner with local artists

November
1                -  Networking Visit
2               -  Flight back to Penang, Malaysia

 

The Impact

We feel the urge to tell a story about our environment. Taiwan is one of our destinations which we think it will bring us a great impact. It is known as one of the countries where product packaging is vibrant and the phenomena of disposable plastic products is a norm. However, taiwanese, at the same time, they promote and advocate the idea of recycle.

This is definitely a great opportunity for us to explore, share and absorb a different perspective of recycle.

 

Risks & Challenges

We will take all the consequences that may come. Any shortages from the crowdfunding, we will bear it ourselves. The trip must go on. We hope our little effort will remind some friends around about the problems of our one and only mother earth has.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Worries not. If you could not help us with financing (like us), you can still help us in:

a) Follow us on Facebook so that you can get more and updates of our rehearsals and any upcoming project / performances

b) Spread out the word to your friends and family

A BIG thank you to those who spend time to understand who are we and what we need.

story:
The Book of Darkness & Light is going on tour – and we need your help to get the show on the road.

Three chilling tales. Two ghostly performers. One thrilling night. 

On an Autumn evening in 2015, two friends told a ghost story to 1,500 people in a dimly-lit church in the centre of Leeds. Now, after a tour to libraries, arts spaces and theatres, Adam and Ben are going back on the road with their thrilling tales and haunting violin accompaniment.

WATCH our show trailer: https://youtu.be/K09MROlwVH0 

Who Are We?

We are Adam Z. Robinson and Ben Styles, Storyteller and Musician, and we need your help to make our tour a success. 

We've been working together on our ghost story shows for a couple of years and we've been thrilled with the response we've received. In fact, it's the kind comments, support and reception from audiences which have pushed us to take the show out for a second tour. This time, everything is under our own steam. It's a huge challenge - but we really want to bring our creepy tales to new venues, towns and audiences. 

The Tour

Spanning 3 months the tour will take us to 22 theatres up and down the country. We've already announced the following dates: Ropery Hall, Barton-upon-Humber (21 Oct), Century Theatre, Coalville (28 Oct), Shelley Theatre, Boscombe (2 Nov), Margate Theatre Royal (4 Nov). But there are many more due to be announced soon. 

Getting the Show on the Road

We need your help! Taking the show to all of these different venues, across all of these different dates, has many costs.

Your gift - however large or small - will help us with: vehicle hire for the tour, putting petrol in the van, hiring technicians, accommodation, equipment hire and marketing costs. Our IndieGoGo target is just a fraction of what we need to raise - but it will make a huge difference. We'd be so grateful if you would consider supporting us. 

The New Show

We're currently working on a brand new set of stories - a brand new Book of Darkness & Light show! We're working in association with Square Chapel Arts Centre and Harrogate Theatre. We really want to bring the new stories to some of the libraries we played at last year. These library shows will be on a Pay What You Decide basis - making them available to everyone. We can only do these shows with your help.

Ghost Story Writing Workshops 

Adam is looking into running a course of ghost story writing workshops. This is a big project and requires lots of time and dedication. But, it's something we really want to do. Again, we need your help to achieve this! (This is one of our 'stretch goals' if we exceed our target). 

Our Target

Our IndieGoGo target is only a small fraction of what we need to raise in order to do all of the things we'd like to. But getting your donations will make a big difference. We hope you will consider supporting us. 

Rewards

Any donations, large or small, would be appreciated immensely. We have a fantastic list of rewards – our original violin soundtrack, unique horror haikus, signed posters and scripts and even a live performance of the show in a venue of your choosing (ghost stories in your living room, anyone?). These are our way to say thank you for whatever you can give.

 

The Book of Darkness & Light Team:

Adam Z. Robinson

Writer and The Storyteller in The Book of Darkness & Light. The first horror movie Adam ever saw was Silver Bullet. He was both terrified and hooked from that moment. Today, his favourite scary movies are The Exorcist, The Wicker Man and The Blair Witch Project. He is obsessed with M.R. James and pretty much all ghost story writers.

Ben Styles

Violinist, composer and The Musician in The Book of Darkness & Light. Ben saw The Mummy when he was 12 and did not like it one bit. In the past few years though he has rediscovered horror and particularly likes the surreal ghost stories of E.F. Benson.

Dick Bonham

Producer (LittleMighty) and Dramaturg for The Book of Darkness & Light. Dick is a massive fan of classic Hammer Horror films, with his favourite being Plague of the Zombies and Quatermass and the Pit. He is a big fan of gothic literature, with his favourites including Shirley Jackson's The Haunting of Hill House.

 

Stretch goals

If this campaign does well and we exceed our target, the extra funds will go towards:

- A course of creative writing workshops 

- Library shows: The brand new show will be taken to various libraries on a Pay What You Decide basis. 

- Further marketing, to make sure we fill every venue.

- More stories and tours going beyond 2017/18.

Risks and challenges

The main risk is that we struggle to pay for the travel to each venue, accommodation for all of the dates and can't afford technical staff members for certain dates. Plus, there is some extra equipment we'd like to hire for bigger auditoria in order to deliver the best show possible. 

The other risk we can foresee is that we don’t secure the audience sizes we are expecting. We feel that this is unlikely – our proposition of a thrilling ghost story with live music in an unusual venue is one that people seem to get behind – but it is a possibility.

We will put everything we can into marketing the show and, as mentioned above, any extra we might raise from this campaign will go towards making sure people know about the events.

story:
G.L.O.R.Y. is back!

Hello again friends! The Glorious Ladies of Rasslin, Y'all are back for a second show and we hope you are all as excited as we are! Thanks to your contributions to our first IndieGoGo this past spring, we were able to accomplish an incredible feat: turning our rag-tag concept of an amateur all-female and non-binary theatrical wrestling league into a reality with our first show, Plague of Blood 1.0.

We put our bleeding hearts and four months of intense work into something nobody had done before, inside a little golden ring we built ourselves. We didn’t know how it would land. We weren’t sure if it would go over. But we put our faith in each other and in ourselves and we were rewarded with THUNDEROUS APPLAUSE and LAUGHTER. It happened because you believed in us.

GLORY wants to continue to bring you our very best. GLORY is a performance project run by students and artists who dedicate their time to training for our shows. While our time is incredibly valuable, it unfortunately does not bankroll production costs for the show. Our goal is to better ourselves with each show, and with your IGG donations we will accomplish AN INSANE EXPLOSION OF FEMALE BLOODSPORT FOR YOUR THIRSTY EYES AND EMPTY HEARTS TO DRINK!

Last IGG we spoke about why GLORY was important. Why this form of wrestling needed a place in this sport. With our first show under our belts, we can say without a shadow of a doubt how satisfying it was for our performers, many of whom had limited or no wrestling or performance experience before that show, and legitimately how much fun we and the crowd had doing this!

If you came to the show last time, THANK YOU. Thank you for telling your friends about us. Supporting GLORY is not limited to your financial contributions alone. Coming up to us and telling us how much you love GLORY is support. Liking our posts on Facebook is support. And if you feel inspired to support us but don’t have the cash, please consider volunteering at our show! (Send us an email - gloryatx@gmail.com)

 

Our Budget

Short Term

Our show budget is a list of our bare-bones budget for our upcoming show. These are the minimal expenses needed to make this show run. We are adamant about paying our performers, and performer/artist/tech crew payout is our largest expense. The rest is production cost, including compensation for the hours of teaching and organizing that go into our show.

Show budget:

$3000 - performer, artist, and tech crew payout

$900 - new merchandise

$500 - ring repairs and updates

$200 - training

$400 - organization and management

$300 - props and costumes

$100 - ring transportation

$100 - A/V rentals

$200 - folding chairs

(Subtotal: $5,700)

Long Term

Many of the moves we are able to do are limited (due to safety precautions) in our current ring. While our updates ensure optimal safety for our performers, it does not allow us to do some of the more dazzling moves that we could do. This is why we have made it our long term goal to buy a professional wrestling ring that will allow our performers to run their matches in future shows to the fullest extent of their imaginations. It’s a big expense, but we think it is attainable within the next year. There will be no losers in this new world. A real wrestling ring will be a win for everyone!

Long term expenses:

$5000 - new ring

$1000 - ring storage

(Subtotal: $6,000)

Total budget: $11,700

 

The $2,800 we ask for today only represents a small portion of our budget, but it is enough to cover our production costs and ensure that our show will happen. The additional money that we need to pay our performers, artists, and tech crew will come from ticket and merch sales. Any extra money we make on our IndieGoGo will go towards paying our performers, and combined with our ticket and merch sales, all extra money after performer payout will be budgeted towards our long term goal of buying a ring!

Thank you; we are so grateful for your support!

The rest is production cost, including compensation for the hours of teaching and organizing that go into our show.
Show budget:
$3000 - performer, artist, and tech crew payout
$900 - new merchandise
$500 - ring repairs and updates
$200 - training
$400 - organization and management
$300 - props and costumes
$100 - ring transportation
$100 - A/V rentals
$200 - folding chairs
(Subtotal: $5,700)
Long Term
Many of the moves we are able to do are limited (due to safety precautions) in our current ring. While our updates ensure optimal safety for our performers, it does not allow us to do some of the more dazzling moves that we could do. This is why we have made it our long term goal to buy a professional wrestling ring that will allow our performers to run their matches in future shows to the fullest extent of their imaginations. It’s a big expense, but we think it is attainable within the next year. There will be no losers in this new world. A real wrestling ring will be a win for everyone!
Long term expenses:
$5000 - new ring
$1000 - ring storage
(Subtotal: $6,000)
Total budget: $11,700 The $2,800 we ask for today only represents a small portion of our budget, but it is enough to cover our production costs and ensure that our show will happen. The additional money that we need to pay our performers, artists, and tech crew will come from ticket and merch sales. Any extra money we make on our IndieGoGo will go towards paying our performers, and combined with our ticket and merch sales, all extra money after performer payout will be budgeted towards our long term goal of buying a ring!
Thank you; we are so grateful for your support!

story:
WE REACHED OUR INITIAL GOAL!! But we aren't done yet – Check out below for our stretch goals and where the money is going. 


Short Summary

Hi, I'm A.J. Brockman, co founder and curator of The Brewhouse Gallery, Lake Park, Florida's only art, coffee and craft beer experience and the driving force behind our campaign to revitalize the Kelsey Theater; Reviving an entire community!

What was once a successful indie film house and rock music venue will become an independently run, community-based, theater that focuses on bringing culture to the surrounding areas through film, music and the performing arts.

While Palm Beach County is known for its affluent theaters our venue will make such events a lot more accessible to a community that is less likely to attend stuffy art shows with expensive admissions. At a 500 person capacity our location fills a much needed niche and bridges the gap between much smaller and much larger clubs. The lobby would consist of a rotating gallery highlighting installation art from local artists and the venue will also act as a community space and a miniature convention center, hosting everything from an indoor green market (grown directly from the community garden feet away) to career fairs, to comic book conventions.


What We Need & What You Get

To achieve this, we need to raise $50,000 but we didn’t just dream this up last night, we’ve been working toward making this a reality for some time now. We also understand this is ambitious so we will be implementing our goals in $10,000 increments and stretch goals. 

We’ve done preliminary lighting and sound build outs as well as having a 3D render of the space already designed. What we need now is the capitol to execute these designs and make this a reality and we simply cannot do that alone. 

But this isn’t just about the satisfaction of making this dream a reality, we have designed our perks to make you, the contributor, a part of this space (Heck, with some of these perks you LITERALLY will be part of the space). Things like movie or show tickets, VIP packages, your name in our floor or a 3D scanned bust of your likeness in our lobby. One contributor could even name our theater, it’s all about how involved you want to be.



The Impact

In a single word, community, that is what this is all about. A venue like this not only serves those who live there but also draws in visitors from neighboring cities. As a result those people eat in our restaurants, shop in our stores and enable local businesses to thrive. Art, culture, entertainment and economic stimulation all under one roof.


Risks & Challenges

The risks are truly very minimal. First, we own the building where the theater is located so there is no risk of losing the space after the renovations are complete. Second, and I want to make this very clear, NONE of the money raised will be put toward employee salaries of any kind. This money is strictly for the physical costs of the build out, everything else we will take care of. We have built a "Dream Team" of dedicated individuals that are not only some of the most well-respected in their individual fields but truly want to be part of our mission and vision. 

As far as something like this succeeding, our best example is the Brewhouse Gallery. Located right next door to the theater, our growth has been phenominal and from speaking to those who visit us regularly I know the community is hungry for something like this to open up. The same people behind that are now behind making this new project something truly special.


Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to contributions we really need your help getting the word out. Word of mouth is always the best way for something like this to gain momentum so please take a moment to share this on your Facebook or Twitter. Tell people you know about what we are trying to do and where they can find out more. Together we can make this happen, and I look forward to seeing you all on opening day!

story:
Project: Humanity asks for your support to present a production of Audio Guides featuring new work by Catherine Murray, with invited work by Andrea Spaziani and Christy Stoeten.

Catherine, Christy & Andy realized that they all had work where sound and language were integral to the audience's experience and interaction with the piece. We decided to bring these three works together around the concept of Audio Guides. We'd love to have your support to help make this production happen.

 The Three Works

/vərˈbādəm/ - Concept and Choreography by Catherine Murray. Created and Performed by Andrea Spaziani, Denise Solleza, and Christy Stoeten. 

"/vərˈbādəm/ centres on how dance, language, and personal experience interact, intersect, and inform each other. Beginning with interview transcripts that I personally conducted, dancers physically represent the conversations by applying a verbatim framework to their "translation." The work explores the opportunity for verbatim text, verbatim movement, and a voice to exist in the same space, attempting to maintain the integrity of all three of these forms which are dependent upon, and derived from, each other."

Rafters - Concept by Andrea Spaziani. Created and Performed in collaboration with Alicia Grant, Julia Male, and Andrea Spaziani.

"Rafters is influence in motion. It flushes out the unconscious, and projects it across a femme triad. It is set to an audio collage of ‘self-talk’ made from words that have emerged through movement, are completely personal, and are also perhaps untrue. The words are the linguistic result of twittering gestural squirms pushed out from deep subliminal tripping. Their influence is mysterious, and they point towards a communication beyond inscription. The performers interact with the audio collage, and each other, floating in and out of a network of influence. This entanglement becomes the material, and the room becomes a space of charged interconnectivity. This dance attunes to the information between words, bodies, and their surroundings."

Until Tender-Crisp III - Created and Performed by Christy Stoeten. This work was created with the support of the Toronto Arts Council and the Series 8:08 Creators Space Residency, 2013/2014.

"Until Tender-Crisp III asks how does seeing something over and over again change it, or our relationship to it? How do our memories shape our present? And how does our present skew our past? This work explores themes that are grounded in daily life experiences, investigating humour in the everyday, and seeking beauty in the mundane. 'It makes me realize that the wool has been pulled over my eyes for years with the whole Wizard of Oz, Dark Side of the Moon rigamarole.' Michelle Rhodes."

What We Need & What You Get

Audio Guides will be presented at The Citadel from March 3 - 5, 2016. This show will feature three separate dance works that are performed by 5 professional dancers, plus choreographers, a stage manager, a lighting designer, and a sound editor working behind the scenes. This fundraising helps us make this production possible.

$3000 might not seem like a lot but it covers almost everything we need to make this production happen. The money we raise will go towards:

  • renting the Citadel for our three shows plus some rehearsal time;
  • remunerating the dancers, our stage manager, and our lighting designer; 
  • renting sound equipment;
  • providing some refreshments to our audience members at the shows.

If we don’t reach our entire goal, whatever you’ve generously donated will go directly into covering as many of the above costs as we can. Every dime counts and every dime helps. We hope that our perks are enough to entice you to give whatever you can. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand if you can’t make a financial donation. But there are other ways to help Audio Guides.

1. Please let all your friends and family know about this Indiegogo campaign. Tweet about it. Facebook about it. Email away. Use the Indiegogo share tools and help us spread the word.

2. If you’re a Toronto business owner and you’d like to get involved in some way – whether it be sponsorship for an ad in our program, or a donation of in-kind services, please get in touch with us at catherine@projecthumanity.ca 

3. Please come see the show! We run from March 3 - 5, 2016 at the Citadel and we’d love to share our work with you.

Who is Project: Humanity?

Project: Humanity (PH) is a Toronto-based non-profit raising social awareness through the arts. Founded by theatre/dance professionals, the company has used drama to foster more understanding and empathy between marginalized groups and the community-at-large – locally in Toronto, provincially and nationally. The company is committed to creating original, socially-minded theatre and dance while maintaining a strong and ongoing community outreach mandate – with a particular emphasis on young people. Previous community partners include Jessie’s (the June Callwood Centre for Young Women), Covenant House Shelter, and most frequently, Youth Without Shelter (YWS).

story:
Hello, all!

Nathan Edwin Keep and Ariel Leigh Cohen here to talk about the show we've co-written, produced and directed AND starring in called "Doing the Thing." 

We met whilst co-starring in a limited engagement of an Off-Off Broadway run in NYC and hit it off immediately. Over the last two years, we have cultivated our comedic skills and banter. Then, fueled by the "anything can happen" attitude of this year's Pride, we decided to create this two person show which details the hardships of 20-something out of work actors. From dating to auditions, we have created something magical that we wish to pursue in different media outlets with our production company Keep it Going Productions.

Your generous donations would go toward: the venue, accompanist, costumes, make-up, props, publicity, liposuction...you know, whatever comes first (kidding about that last bit!). Without your help, this first venture will halt any plans for future projects, as we are currently paying out of pocket and are the epitome of those 20-something out of work actors we described.

We have plenty of fantastic incentives in return for your valiant efforts towards helping the creative endeavors of our youth. In other words, we need your help!

For more information and updates, please visit our Facebook page "Doing the Thing" and like us, so we can feel the validation, like a ray of NYC sunshine!

Thank you so much and we look forward to working with you!

Nathan & Ariel

story:
The DwC All-Star Impact

The Dancing with Class All-Stars (www.dwcallstars.org) provides free ballroom and social dance training to middle school students from across Chicago, with an emphasis on serving under-resourced communities.  Innovative programs that provide social support and development are increasingly urgent. The All-Stars offers a unique solution by expanding access to an art form and social activity that inherently builds leadership skills, self-confidence and tolerance.

“I see our All -Stars unite across social groups and differences, master complicated material, gain confidence, become leaders, and develop discipline. But most of all I see our All -Stars discovering joy through social dance, and I am so proud to help bring joy to these very special young dancers.”-- Artistic Director Chris Van Houten
More than 250 students have been served since  inception, representing dozens of Chicago Public Schools across the city. Most DwC All-Stars have been participants in the Dancing with Class – Core Program, which serves 60+ CPS elementary schools and more than 3,000 students per year.


What Your Contribution Achieves

The program relies on individual contributions to help these talented kids continue their training and reach their dancing goals.  The All-Stars have many ambitions for the year ahead, including:

• Entering their first-ever large-scale dance competition

• Pioneering a new dance scholarship program for high school students

• Attending and Performing in the 2016 Chicago International Salsa Congress

• New costumes, new choreography, new performance opportunities

All contributions go directly to support the training and development of kids in the program.

Whether or not you are able to make a financial contribution, we also invite you to join us for the DWC ALL-STARS BOOGIE WALK!


The Boogie Walk is a dance-infused walk-a-thon presented in partnership with the Chicago Park District's Park Family Wellness Initiative and the Chicago Public Schools Office of Student Health and Wellness. In addition to the walk-a-thon fundraiser, the event includes free dance instruction and activities presented by various food and fitness partners. 

Where: Kilbourn Park, 3501 N Kilbourn Ave, Chicago, IL 60641

When:  September 26th 10am - 12pm

Register here!  https://www.eventbrite.com/e/2015-boogie-walk-t... 

We ask that walkers donate or raise a minimum of $20  (T-shirt and goodies included).  Grand Prizes will be awarded to the top Child and Adult fundraiser. Spectators can join for free.

To support a specific Boogie Walk participant: Donate ANY AMOUNT through this campaign page and let the walker know that you have made this contribution so they can log it on their pledge sheet!

***

Another way to help is to share links to this campaign page with your networks. An email to friends with a link to this campaign is especially helpful. You can also share the link via Facebook, Twitter and other Social Media.


                                                                        

Thank you for inspiring a new generation of dancers to dream big and achieve excellence! 


Dancing with Class All-Stars is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Dancing with Class All-Stars must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. The value of each perk is noted when perk is selected. Any contribution above that amount is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
**DONATIONS TO THIS CAMPAIGN ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE**

ABOUT THE SHOW

Hi everyone, Anna here. I have been working on MYTHO? Lure of Wildness on and off for almost three years now. Starting the project with my incredible director, Caleb Hammond, it has grown and grown to include four other performers and a production team of ten! It is an ambitious production but already it is looking beautiful and I can't wait to share it with you at our world premiere at Abrons Arts Center this December. 

MYTHO? examines the relationship between muse and creator, subject and object, model and artist and what is at the vital center of the creative mind. Through a combination of live performance, video, ASMR and aromas, you, the audience will be transported through my memories: My artistic awakening as a young model in France, my coming of age - a world of heightened vulnerability and sensuality, you will be immersed in a sensory experience of enhanced stimuli and vivid images. 

Amongst our team are downtown video legends Shaun Irons and Lauren Petty, as well as the indomitable Bill Kennedy and queer performance artist Hapi Phace. Sound design comes from Carnegie Mellon grad Almeda Beynon and lighting from Jeffrey Nash. Hapi and I will be joined on stage by Katiana Rangel, Alenka Kraigher and Adam Strandberg. It's a wonderful team!

This is a photo of some of us at a week long script intensive in Western Massachusetts this Summer. 

You can find out more about the show itself (and buy tickets) here or about my other work, here.

WHAT WE NEED

Although I have received some support from grants these only cover a portion of our total costs. We're running a campaign to raise an extra $11,500 and this money will go towards paying the incredible team behind this show and some of the costs associated with transporting and housing our Boston based performers and designers. These people are going above and beyond for this project, some of of them have been with this project from the very beginning and I really want to be able to thank them.

 

WHAT YOUR DONATION WILL DO

Your contribution will make a huge difference to how much we can pay our artists. They are working so hard and we want them to be happy and healthy while they bring MYTHO? to life.

Presenting this work is very significant to me. Although I have been working as an artist for decades, this is the first time I have led a production of this scale. I conceived, wrote, and am performing in MYTHO? Lure of Wildness - it is exciting and scary and your donation is a wonderful vote of support!

This is also the first time I have turned to you, my community to ask for this kind of support. Please take the time to watch our video, take a look at the perks and, if you can, give! Any contribution counts. 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Tell your friends, share this link on facebook or by email: https://igg.me/at/mythoannakohler

And come to the show, we'd love to see you there!

TICKETS NOW AVAILABLE FOR PURCHASE HERE!

**DONATIONS TO THIS CAMPAIGN ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE**

ABOUT ME

Stage and screen author, actor and director Anna Kohler laid the foundation for her work studying at the Mozarteum in Salzburg, Austria and getting her diploma in theater and aesthetic studies from the Université VIII Vincennes in Paris, France. Since joining the New York experimental theater scene in 1982, she has worked on stage with some of America’s most respected playwrights, actors and directors, and was a longtime collaborator and associate member of America’s foremost experimental theater company The Wooster Group. Her film work includes Raoul Ruiz’sThe Golden Boat, Hal Hartley’s The Book of Life, Bruno de Almeida’s On the Run and Peter Sellars’ The Cabinet of Dr. Ramirez, among others. As an author/director, she has conceived and directed plays that have been performed in Austria, Germany, Brazil, and the United States.

annakohler.com

ABOUT CALEB HAMMOND

Caleb Hammond is a teacher and creator of theater and visual art. He has taught theater and art at Eugene Lang College (The New School), Hartford Art School and Carnegie Mellon. He has been a special guest lecturer at Colgate University and the Toyoma Glass Institute in Japan.

Directing work includes: Prop 8, staged reading at Carnegie Mellon, featuring The Book of Mormon's Rory O’Malley; 1000 Wolves at Incubator Arts Project, NYC; Walks Through Walls at Highways Performance Space, Los Angeles; How Delightful to Know Mr Lear, in the New Haven Festival of Arts and Ideas; Mac Wellman's Antigone at Carnegie Mellon; SICK at UndergroundZero Festival NYC and FIRE (sex and death), at Divaldo Kampa, Prague. Acting credits include: Hal Hartley's films Ned Rifle and Meanwhile; John Jesurun’s webseries Shadowland; Sam Shepard's True West, at the Factory Theater, Boston; Tennessee William's The Demolition Downtown, at the Provincetown Williams Festival. He was a regular featured performer in Jay Scheib’s work including: the Obie-award winning Untitled Mars, at PS122, NYC and the National Theater of Hungary; Bellona, Destroyer of Cities, at the Kitchen, NYC and Maison des Arts, Paris; and This Place is a Desert: Under the Radar Festival, The Public Theater NYC and Boston ICA.

 

Anna Kohler is a sponsored artist with The Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Anna Kohler are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or for our national charities registration. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.
story_txt:
**DONATIONS TO THIS CAMPAIGN ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE**ABOUT THE SHOWHi everyone, Anna here. I have been working on MYTHO? Lure of Wildness on and off for almost three years now. Starting the project with my incredible director, Caleb Hammond, it has grown and grown to include four other performers and a production team of ten! It is an ambitious production but already it is looking beautiful and I can't wait to share it with you at our world premiere at Abrons Arts Center this December. MYTHO? examines the relationship between muse and creator, subject and object, model and artist and what is at the vital center of the creative mind. Through a combination of live performance, video, ASMR and aromas, you, the audience will be transported through my memories: My artistic awakening as a young model in France, my coming of age - a world of heightened vulnerability and sensuality, you will be immersed in a sensory experience of enhanced stimuli and vivid images. Amongst our team are downtown video legends Shaun Irons and Lauren Petty, as well as the indomitable Bill Kennedy and queer performance artist Hapi Phace. Sound design comes from Carnegie Mellon grad Almeda Beynon and lighting from Jeffrey Nash. Hapi and I will be joined on stage by Katiana Rangel, Alenka Kraigher and Adam Strandberg. It's a wonderful team!This is a photo of some of us at a week long script intensive in Western Massachusetts this Summer. You can find out more about the show itself (and buy tickets) here or about my other work, here.WHAT WE NEEDAlthough I have received some support from grants these only cover a portion of our total costs. We're running a campaign to raise an extra $11,500 and this money will go towards paying the incredible team behind this show and some of the costs associated with transporting and housing our Boston based performers and designers. These people are going above and beyond for this project, some of of them have been with this project from the very beginning and I really want to be able to thank them. WHAT YOUR DONATION WILL DOYour contribution will make a huge difference to how much we can pay our artists. They are working so hard and we want them to be happy and healthy while they bring MYTHO? to life.Presenting this work is very significant to me. Although I have been working as an artist for decades, this is the first time I have led a production of this scale. I conceived, wrote, and am performing in MYTHO? Lure of Wildness - it is exciting and scary and your donation is a wonderful vote of support!This is also the first time I have turned to you, my community to ask for this kind of support. Please take the time to watch our video, take a look at the perks and, if you can, give! Any contribution counts. OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELPTell your friends, share this link on facebook or by email: https://igg.me/at/mythoannakohlerAnd come to the show, we'd love to see you there!
TICKETS NOW AVAILABLE FOR PURCHASE HERE!**DONATIONS TO THIS CAMPAIGN ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE**ABOUT MEStage and screen author, actor and director Anna Kohler laid the foundation for her work studying at the Mozarteum in Salzburg, Austria and getting her diploma in theater and aesthetic studies from the Université VIII Vincennes in Paris, France. Since joining the New York experimental theater scene in 1982, she has worked on stage with some of America’s most respected playwrights, actors and directors, and was a longtime collaborator and associate member of America’s foremost experimental theater company The Wooster Group. Her film work includes Raoul Ruiz’sThe Golden Boat, Hal Hartley’s The Book of Life, Bruno de Almeida’s On the Run and Peter Sellars’ The Cabinet of Dr. Ramirez, among others. As an author/director, she has conceived and directed plays that have been performed in Austria, Germany, Brazil, and the United States.annakohler.comABOUT CALEB HAMMONDCaleb Hammond is a teacher and creator of theater and visual art. He has taught theater and art at Eugene Lang College (The New School), Hartford Art School and Carnegie Mellon. story:
The Deep

5pm - Thursday 29th June 2017 - The Old Fire Station Studio, Oxford

A day in the life of one man and the fishing community that sustains him. A day in which he must face his fears and desires amongst the ice-cold waters off the coast of Iceland in a desperate attempt to survive. Based on a remarkable true story, Presence Theatre returns to explore Jón Atli Jónasson's monologue after a reading at the Embassy of Iceland.

Samuel Edward-Cook once again plays the solo role, supported by an immersive soundscape by the award-winning sound designer David Gregory and directed by Jack Tarlton.

 

“I am thrilled that Offbeat have invited Presence Theatre to present The Deep as a work in progress, allowing myself and Sam the opportunity to further investigate Jón Atli Jónasson's extraordinary play. I see this presentation very much as the next stepping-stone towards mounting a full production in the near future, building on past successes the company has had with Nordic drama. If you are able to help towards the cost of mounting this reading we would be immensely grateful. No contribution is too small, and it will allow us not only to share The Deep with a new audience, but will enable the company to grow and develop even further. Thank you.”

Jack Tarlton, Joint Artistic Director

 

"A direct and fully felt performance ... Samuel Edward-Cook shares this fisherman’s difficult journey with every one of his audience, creating powerful theatre ... an impressive achievement." British Theatre Guide

For the full review please go to http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/reviews/the-deep-13777

 

"The energy and imagination sitting under Presence Theatre inspires me. The rigour of their workshops and the breadth and democracy of their Reading Group compliment their production back history beautifully. People of real taste and intelligence running a company with integrity and grace."  Simon Stephens

What we need:

We need to raise £700 to cover the costs of creative fees, advertising material and rights. Simply that. All money raised will go directly to the project, even if we don't reach the goal. It will happen. 

If we exceed our target it will go towards securing the rights for the planned fully realised production.

IN ORDER FOR THIS TO HAPPEN WE NEED YOUR HELP. PLEASE GIVE WHATEVER YOU CAN, HOWEVER SMALL, AND ONCE YOU HAVE DONATED PLEASE SHARE THIS PAGE AS FAR AND WIDE AS POSSIBLE.​

 

You can find more about Presence Theatre at www.presencetheatre.com , @PresenceTheatre on Twitter and https://www.facebook.com/PresenceTheatre on Facebook

story:
Update: here is a video of Emily and Ben performing at EAAC 2013: 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QiyA1T2x98g


The Basics:

Hello! Thanks for taking a look at our crowdfunding page! We are Emily Nicholl and Ben Collis, and we are acrobats from Edinburgh, Scotland. You may have seen us training, teaching and performing around Edinburgh, the UK and Europe.

In order to take our skills to the next level, and represent Scotland at the top level of contemporary Circus around the world, we are going to train at Flic Circus School in Torino, Italy. We start on the 28th September 2013.

We would love it if you could make this possible for us! Any money you donate will contribute directly to our development as circus professionals, and enable us to give more back to the circus community in Scotland.


About Flic:

Torino is a beautiful and historic city in North-Western Italy, right at the foot of the Alps. But most importantly it is home to Flic Circus School, a high level contemporary circus preparation and finishing school, and member of the European Federation of Professional Circus Schools (FEDEC)

We have chosen Flic (and feel honoured to have been accepted on their course) because of its reputation for technical training alongside theatre and creation, its excellent acrobatics training and top level teachers and artistic directors. Throughout the course students put on monthly free performances in order to gain performance experience, try out new ideas, get audience feedback and provide free performances to the local community. It has an incredible atmosphere, offering a disciplined and challenging education, whilst emphasising creativity, support and community between students and teachers.

From the FEDEC website (http://www.fedec.eu/flic_scuola_di_formazione_arti_circensi.1671.html):

“FLIC Circus School is located in the Reale Società Ginnastica historical building in central Turin.

Their principal objective is to give all the students a strong education in contemporary circus from every angle: acrobatic and physical training, circus artistry, contemporary dance and all the circus disciplines.
The second year is dedicated to the development of a specialist circus discipline chosen by each student.”


The Costs:

We are asking for donations to help cover our tuition fees, which are 2900 euros each per year.

For full time circus training at a renowned professional circus school, we feel this to be extremely reasonable. We will gain invaluable experience and connections, broadening our network of contacts and friends within the European circus community. It is a full time course, with training 5 days a week and monthly performances and monthly specialised workshops from visiting teachers, so we will also gain skills that we could not achieve otherwise. We estimate it will cost us a total of £7000 each to complete a year at Flic.

We have been working hard to get the money together to live for a year whilst studying full-time in Italy. We have been teaching workshops, performing, doing odd jobs and selling all our possessions! We are extremely appreciative of any donations or words of support, and promise to be totally responsible with your generosity and only ever spend your donations on our circus development.

We have created a series of rewards that we hope will mean something to you, from a big heartfelt thank you for changing our lives, to a unique piece of acrobatic artwork, to workshops and your very own personalised performance.


Giving back:

We have a real passion for our home grown circus community and for the power that circus has to change peoples lives. We will become strong physical performers at the highest level of technical circus ability, and create innovative, original and inspiring circus. We look forward to collaborating across art forms and creating exchanges between Italy and Scotland. We believe that skills should be shared and so we will spread our new skills and techniques as far as we can, around the world and in our Scottish circus community through teaching and training as well as performance.


How to Help:

Besides donating to us here on Indiegogo, you can also make a real difference by sharing this page. Tell your friends, Email it to your colleagues, post it on Facebook, Tweet it (There are tools on the Indiegogo page to do all those things). Anything you can do to get the word out will help us, as will any words of encouragement and good luck. We sincerely appreciate it!

We hugely appreciate you taking the time to read this and watch our video. Please get in touch if you have any questions or want to say hello, we would love to hear from you!



Our Bio:

We have been training acrobatics together for two and a half years. We are both Edinburgh based but find ourselves all over the UK and Europe on a regular basis. Our training started with the brilliant skill sharing acrobalance/dance/circus community in Edinburgh and has since included European Acro Conventions, NoFitState Circus, Conflux, Luxe, Mimbre, Wybren Wouda, Fons Bennnk, Vertigo Circus School, Flic Circus School, Angela de Castro, Wired Aerial Theatre, tePOOKa and Beltane Fire Society. We have performed in numerous contexts including at NoFitState Circus, MintFest, Chatsworth House and most notably at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival

Ben has been training in partner acrobatics and hand to hand for 5 years He also trains in solo acrobatics and dance. In performances he always aims to be creative and original, with every movement telling a story. Ben originally experienced acro at the very first Edinburgh Aerial and Acro Convention in 2008, and has been addicted ever since. He is probably thinking about acrobatics right now...

Exploring performance and political theatre whilst working in environmental education with young people, Emily became inspired by circus and physical theatre as a means to merge them all together. She began training partner acrobatics in 2011. Having recently finished a year as a trainee performer with NoFitState Circus, she now focuses on hand to hand, acro-dance and solo handstands. She is a passionate teacher and learner, inspired by the challenging yet empowering nature of partner acrobatics. She also has a growing interest in rigging for circus performance and is often found enjoying scaring herself whilst rock climbing.



THANK YOU!!!!

story:
...Are you feeling FIERCE?

2014 is Fierce Backbone’s 7th year developing plays and people for the stage in Los Angeles. Fierce Backbone’s Play Lab meets every Monday night, exploring new works while engaging in lively discussions to serve each individual play. That’s more than 300 MONDAY NIGHT PLAY LABS to date…and we’re still going!

Just in the last year, we've produced a daring show called THE BEATING and the critically acclaimed A GOOD GRIEF. Both developed and honed through the collaboration of Fierce artists. Our artists have also been seen on the big and small screen, become published novelists, and had plays developed at Fierce performed on stages all over the country. 

Our creative doors are always open to like-minded artists who want to join us or simply pay a visit every now and then. Throughout the year, Fierce Backbone serves more than 100 actors, playwrights, directors, designers and technical/support staff in the presentation of new work for the stage. We believe there is room for all artistic voices and all talents when the spirit of collaboration is shared. We have big plans for 2014 that include the Hollywood Fringe Festival, more workshops and staged readings and another full production from one of our writers.

Please join us as we raise funds to support our 2014 Season, which kicks off with The Hollywood Fringe Festival, and you can directly support Fierce artists. Here’s what your tax-deductible gift will do…

$25 Sponsors an artist for one month of workshop.

$50 Buys props or costumes for a Fringe show!

$100 Covers our rent for one night of weekly workshop.

$250 Pays our quarterly insurance needed for programming.

$500 Supports one of our Staged Readings.

Your gift makes you part of the Fierce Family and, just so you know, when it comes to family…we throw a really great party. No horrible in-laws invited!

MORE ABOUT FIERCE BACKBONE: January 28, 2008. That was the beginning of Fierce Backbone. What started with 7 people and an idea of how to develop new plays through cold reading, script-in-hand staging and feedback has grown steadily (we now have more than 40 members) for over FIVE YEARS. That’s more than 250 Monday night workshops and countless more hours dedicated to rehearsals and development processes dedicated to advancing the stories most important to our artists, no matter what the subject matter. Since the beginning, Fierce has created more than a dozen workshop productions and even more fully staged readings. 2012 saw the mounting of our very first full production, The Rock of Abandon. Please visit us at our Monday Night Lab every week (except holidays) at the Elephant Theatre in Hollywood. Or check out our website for upcoming productions and other special events on our calendar. www.fiercebackbone.com

story:
You know, listen, I mean, this is gonna be a great show, it really, really is. It's gonna be one of the most luxurious, classy shows in the history of the Capital Fringe Festival. It's really gonna be huge.

I mean, it's beautiful! It's really beautiful, the way that this show imagines a Trump presidency through the lens of Aaron Sorkin's seminal political drama, THE WEST WING. It's really something else.

We're gonna do a lot of great things with this show. We've got a great cast and crew, they're wonderful, wonderful people. They really understand what we need to do to make this country great again (for example, supporting and participating in local theater).

And we are completely self-funding the show. We're not taking any money from the Super PACs that have supported so many other failed shows over the years. (Bad!) We are completely self-funding, all by ourselves, and we would like for you to help us completely self-fund the show with a small donation to help cover the festival fees and marketing costs.

So do us a favor, help us out if you can, and this July, come see us Make Fringe Great Again. (Even though Fringe is already Great.)

LET TRUMP BE TRUMP
by John Krizel
directed by Paul Lysek
Capital Fringe Festival, July 8-23, 2016

We are completely self-funding, all by ourselves, and we would like for you to help us completely self-fund the show with a small donation to help cover the festival fees and marketing costs.
So do us a favor, help us out if you can, and this July, come see us Make Fringe Great Again. (Even though Fringe is already Great.)
LET TRUMP BE TRUMPby John Krizeldirected by Paul LysekCapital Fringe Festival, July 8-23, 2016

story:
Hi, I'm Alex Hersler, the writer/producer of Algorithmism, which will have its world premiere at the 20th annual New York International Fringe Festival this August. I’m super excited because this is going to be the first production of a full length play of mine, but I need your help to actually bring the production to life!

Is Creativity Uniquely Human?

            We’re living through a seismic shift in the structure of society. Artificial Intelligence is getting smarter and more complex every day, and it is already beginning to rival some of the intellectual capabilities of humans. But when it comes to making art, is the process ultimately describable in its totality by algorithms and neural networks, or is there something baked into the concept of creativity that makes it impossible for AI to rival a human artist?

Why do we respond to art? And why do we respond to art differently when we know it’s made by a machine?

            These are questions that are going to help shape the way we design AI. And they are questions that are going to help inform our relationship with art. As the intersection of art and technology grows and evolves, I think it’s very important that we ask ourselves: why do we want machines creating art? I believe that any work today that is a part of the conversation about our relationship with AI is going to help us move into our future more fully equipped.

With your help, we can bring this important topic to the New York stage!

           This play is about two men who have become emotionally intertwined over a ten year relationship, and who discover how desperately they need the other to appreciate their true value in the world. Paul, a famous painter whose immediacy in the art world is fading, champions human-made art, while his agent, Tom, whose reputation for having excellent taste is growing, champions the inclusion of machine-made art. The two find themselves on opposite sides of history after the world learns that a machine is autonomously making art that is commanding top-tier prices.

            Ultimately, the play is a fast-paced tale about art and AI that unfolds as an explosive power struggle between two characters who are super fun to watch.

Where I'm Coming From

           I moved to New York in early 2014 from Oakland, CA to refocus my life around theatre and specifically around playwriting. I studied theater, philosophy and creative writing at Northwestern University, where I first got excited about the synthesis of big ideas and live performance.

            I initially got turned on to the intricacies and existential questions surrounding the trajectory of artificial intelligence through a post on the blog waitbutwhy. The topic of AI is hugely multi-faceted and I find its implications deeply inspiring. I wrote this play as a part of a much larger conversation.

And your support will help drive this conversation forward!

The Nuts and Bolts

I'm asking for $6000, which is going to go directly toward funding the hard costs of the production. Here's a breakdown of how the funding is going to be used:

Actor/Designer/Production Team Stipends - $2700
Set/Props - $300
Costumes - $200
Rehearsal Space - $600
Marketing Materials - $700
Publicity - $700
Insurance - $400
Copy costs (several drafts of play) - $250
Travel Reimbursement - $175
Playbills - $300
Fringe Participation Fee - $700
Venue Director Tip - $100

=$7125. I plan to recoup the difference through ticket sales.

Your Networks...

Please consider spreading the word through social media! To your network of humans... through your network of computers...

Links

If you're interested in learning more about AI/the future of AI/the intersection of AI and art, check out some of these awesome resources.

Wait But Why - Artificial Intelligence Revolution  - long read but ultimately worth it. This is what catalyzed my deeper interest in the future of AI

Excellent and Digestible Primer on Machine Learning

Humans Need Not Apply - Elements of this video were hugely inspiring in writing this play

Alt-AI  - A recent conference in NYC that had a wide range of presenters that exist at the intersection of art and AI

Robots Can't Dance - An interview with Ken Goldberg that is focused more specifically on creativity in humans vs. machines

A Deeper Look into Google’s Deepmind
