story:
Con-nect! ART as a bridge between the lands and cultures...

    Scroll down for Turkish - Turkce icin ekrani asagi indiriniz
 
    I, as an individual artist, am against violence. I do think it's time we human beings evolve into a better state where we all accept each other as we choose to be and stop judging or trying to force others to think as we think. Freedom of speech, expression should be a right not a privilege. Art is a common language for all human beings. It is also a messenger of truth, honesty, reality, purity and most importantly HOPE.. and my HOPE is to build many bridges of con-nection through this powerful form in our  Fall / Spring 2013 - 2014 Season.

    We have some very exciting projects coming up and I am very happy to share them with you.. All our dancers both in NY and in Istanbul are very excited to be a part of the upcoming process, travels and teachings / sharing the experience with the youngsters who maybe has never been exposed to art in such a way..
 
Bridge 1: Multicultural Festival
    After a busy, productive and recently roughened couple months back in my homeland Istanbul, I am back in New York, for a period of time, to mend my heart through making some new work and sharing some work from the previous process in Istanbul. I will be choreographing two new works for two young energetic NY based companies, Mari Meade Dance Collective and Project 44.. The two quartets I will be setting on 4 female and 4 male dancers will premiere by the end of July, in the Between the Seas Festival produced by Aktina Stathaki.. An amazing festival which brings many artists from the Mediterranean countries and have them share their works with the NY audience.
 
Birdge 2: "Come, come whoever you are" - Rumi
    I have premiered a new work called "HEVA" in Istanbul through the end of May, before things started getting rough. In Heva, I only had an image, a sitting man in the middle of the stage as a starting image -one as a whole, the whole in one-, searching for something, seeking something.. Then another man joins in with him and the connection begins, the story starts and the relationship builds up from there. That sitting man "Rumi" and his most beloved friend "Shams of Thabriz".. For another amazing showcase held at Peridance of NY in mid August, I will be bringing Evrim Akyay, who was recently performing with the Jerusalem Dance Theater of Israel and who came back to Istanbul for a couple months and joined our process, took part in Heva, my latest creation. It has been quite a long time since we last danced, took breathe and be present together on the stage, but when we re-united after all these years, the result was stunning.. Our duet received many compliments from the audience and before bringing Heva to New York in the Spring - Summer of 2014, I am so humbled and excited to share this duet with the New York dance scene..
 
Bridge 3: Cultural Exposure
   I also am so proud and excited to let you all know that I am holding an audition in August at Peridance, NY -http://peridance.com/- to take some of the dancers with me to Turkey so we can expand the piece, make it even more inter cultural and multinational as I believe through art it is possible to share hope, change the world and humanity for the better.. And "dance" is such a human form of art that every individual finds a way to connect with it..
 
Bridge 4: Professional Dancers & Children
    Throughout the whole season of Fall 2013 - Spring 2014, with the American and Turkish dancers together, we plan on holding several workshops for the kids in Turkey wherever we tour the piece.. These kids, who might not have had the opportunity to experience art, will not only witness the work of art but will participate in the process of being an artist.
 
    With this campaign my goal to raise at least $23,000.. Which will include the flights of the American and Turkish dancers (6 on the total) from NY to Istanbul, and cover at least 50 hours of rehearsal space, costume fees, accommodation of the dancers and some extra expenses for administrative stuff.. Though I am still seeking some sponsorship for the flights and such, so I decided to keep my limit at $7,777 and see how things build up.. But anything beyond that will be used wisely and creatively..
 
    Giving $1 is not little.. Your support is needed for these projects to be heard, recognized, to be known and be supported by others.. If you can, please do support and share with others, if you don't have the economy to do so, please help spread the word.. Help me build this bridge of hope and art as this is a very important time in my country's history
 

    What your contributions will cover:

    (July)
     - The studio rental fee for the new productions in collaboration with Mari Meade Dance Collective and Project 44 which we are going to premiere within the Between the Seas Festival..

     - Some other administrative fees that needs being spent..
     - Costume for the new pieces..

    (August)
     - Airfare for bringing a Turkish dancer from Istanbul to perform with me..
     - Accommodation for the dancer and other expenses..
     - We also will be holding a private performance in late August for our supporters based in NY followed by a cocktail..
     - Rehearsal period studio rental fee for the showcase in mid-August..
 
    (September)
     - Airfare for bringing 4 American dancers to Istanbul to participate in the performances in Istanbul with the Turkish dancers..
     - Accommodation (partially) expenses of the dancers..
     - Workshops organized in Anatolia, when the company tours in Turkey.. (throughout the year)

 

    Con-nect! Sanat araciligiyla olusturulan kulturlerarasi kopru..

    Bu kampanya araciligiyla toplamda $23,000'lik bir butce olusturmaya calisiyorum. Bu butce ile Temmuz ayi boyunca Mari Meade Dance Collective ve Project 44 adli iki genc topluluga yapacagim iki yeni parcanin prova masraflari, kostum masraflari da bu butceden karsilanacatir.. Temmuz sonunda Between the Seas Festivali'nde promiyer yapcak olan bu parcalar daha sonra topluluklarin repertuarlarinda oynanmaya devam edilecektir.

    Mayis sonunda Istanbul'da gerceklestirdigim "Heva" adli gosteriyi 2014 baharinda NY'a tasimayi planliyorum. Bu uzun soluklu proje icin oncelikle Agustos 17 ve 18'de Istanbul'dan Evrim Akyay adli beraber dans ettigim danciyi konuk olarak davet ediyorum. Bu danscinin ucusu, kalisi ve diger bazi masraflari da elbette bu butceden cikarilacak. Daha sonra Agustos ayi icinde NY'ta gerceklestirdigim bir secme ile NY'tan sececegim danscilari Istanbul'a bu projeye katmak amaciyla tasimak istiyorum.. Yanimda Istanbul'a goturmek istedigim NY'lu danscilarin ucuslarinin bir kismini, hem NY'ta hem Istanbul'da kalis masraflarimizin bir kismini karsilamak istiyorum en azindan bizim icin bir baslangic olucak bu butce. Agustos ayinda ayrica NY'tan bizi destekleyen kisiler icin ozel bir gosterim gerceklestiricez.. Daha sonra Ekim gibi Istanbul'da da yapilmasi planlanmaktadir.

    Bir yandan sponsorluklar aranmaya devam ederken bir yandan ayaklarimin uzerinde durup, sanatimla cagdas bir sekilde kendimi ifade etmeye devam edip, tecrubelerimi, ogrendiklerimi etrafimdakilerle paylasmaya devam edicem.
story_txt:
Con-nect! ART as a bridge between the lands and cultures...
    Scroll down for Turkish - Turkce icin ekrani asagi indiriniz
 
    I, as an individual artist, am against violence. I do think it's time we human beings evolve into a better state where we all accept each other as we choose to be and stop judging or trying to force others to think as we think. Freedom of speech, expression should be a right not a privilege. Art is a common language for all human beings. It is also a messenger of truth, honesty, reality, purity and most importantly HOPE.. and my HOPE is to build many bridges of con-nection through this powerful form in our  Fall / Spring 2013 - 2014 Season.     We have some very exciting projects coming up and I am very happy to share them with you.. All our dancers both in NY and in Istanbul are very excited to be a part of the upcoming process, travels and teachings / sharing the experience with the youngsters who maybe has never been exposed to art in such a way..
 
Bridge 1: Multicultural Festival
    After a busy, productive and recently roughened couple months back in my homeland Istanbul, I am back in New York, for a period of time, to mend my heart through making some new work and sharing some work from the previous process in Istanbul. I will be choreographing two new works for two young energetic NY based companies, Mari Meade Dance Collective and Project 44.. The two quartets I will be setting on 4 female and 4 male dancers will premiere by the end of July, in the Between the Seas Festival produced by Aktina Stathaki.. An amazing festival which brings many artists from the Mediterranean countries and have them share their works with the NY audience.
 
Birdge 2: "Come, come whoever you are" - Rumi
    I have premiered a new work called "HEVA" in Istanbul through the end of May, before things started getting rough. In Heva, I only had an image, a sitting man in the middle of the stage as a starting image -one as a whole, the whole in one-, searching for something, seeking something.. Then another man joins in with him and the connection begins, the story starts and the relationship builds up from there. That sitting man "Rumi" and his most beloved friend "Shams of Thabriz".. For another amazing showcase held at Peridance of NY in mid August, I will be bringing Evrim Akyay, who was recently performing with the Jerusalem Dance Theater of Israel and who came back to Istanbul for a couple months and joined our process, took part in Heva, my latest creation. It has been quite a long time since we last danced, took breathe and be present together on the stage, but when we re-united after all these years, the result was stunning.. Our duet received many compliments from the audience and before bringing Heva to New York in the Spring - Summer of 2014, I am so humbled and excited to share this duet with the New York dance scene..
 
Bridge 3: Cultural Exposure
   I also am so proud and excited to let you all know that I am holding an audition in August at Peridance, NY -http://peridance.com/- to take some of the dancers with me to Turkey so we can expand the piece, make it even more inter cultural and multinational as I believe through art it is possible to share hope, change the world and humanity for the better.. And "dance" is such a human form of art that every individual finds a way to connect with it..
 
Bridge 4: Professional Dancers & Children
    Throughout the whole season of Fall 2013 - Spring 2014, with the American and Turkish dancers together, we plan on holding several workshops for the kids in Turkey wherever we tour the piece.. These kids, who might not have had the opportunity to experience art, will not only witness the work of art but will participate in the process of being an artist.
 
    With this campaign my goal to raise at least $23,000.. Which will include the flights of the American and Turkish dancers (6 on the total) from NY to Istanbul, and cover at least 50 hours of rehearsal space, costume fees, accommodation of the dancers and some extra expenses for administrative stuff.. Though I am still seeking some sponsorship for the flights and such, so I decided to keep my limit at $7,777 and see how things build up.. But anything beyond that will be used wisely and creatively..
 
    Giving $1 is not little.. Your support is needed for these projects to be heard, recognized, to be known and be supported by others.. If you can, please do support and share with others, if you don't have the economy to do so, please help spread the word.. Help me build this bridge of hope and art as this is a very important time in my country's history
 
    What your contributions will cover:
    (July)

     - The studio rental fee for the new productions in collaboration with Mari Meade Dance Collective and Project 44 which we are going to premiere within the Between the Seas Festival..
     - Some other administrative fees that needs being spent..     - Costume for the new pieces..
    (August)

     - Airfare for bringing a Turkish dancer from Istanbul to perform with me..
     - Accommodation for the dancer and other expenses..
     - We also will be holding a private performance in late August for our supporters based in NY followed by a cocktail..
     - Rehearsal period studio rental fee for the showcase in mid-August..
 
    (September)

     - Airfare for bringing 4 American dancers to Istanbul to participate in the performances in Istanbul with the Turkish dancers..
     - Accommodation (partially) expenses of the dancers..
     - Workshops organized in Anatolia, when the company tours in Turkey.. (throughout the year)
 
    Con-nect! Sanat araciligiyla olusturulan kulturlerarasi kopru..
    Bu kampanya araciligiyla toplamda $23,000'lik bir butce olusturmaya calisiyorum. Bu butce ile Temmuz ayi boyunca Mari Meade Dance Collective ve Project 44 adli iki genc topluluga yapacagim iki yeni parcanin prova masraflari, kostum masraflari da bu butceden karsilanacatir.. Temmuz sonunda Between the Seas Festivali'nde promiyer yapcak olan bu parcalar daha sonra topluluklarin repertuarlarinda oynanmaya devam edilecektir.
    Mayis sonunda Istanbul'da gerceklestirdigim "Heva" adli gosteriyi 2014 baharinda NY'a tasimayi planliyorum. Bu uzun soluklu proje icin oncelikle Agustos 17 ve 18'de Istanbul'dan Evrim Akyay adli beraber dans ettigim danciyi konuk olarak davet ediyorum. Bu danscinin ucusu, kalisi ve diger bazi masraflari da elbette bu butceden cikarilacak. Daha sonra Agustos ayi icinde NY'ta gerceklestirdigim bir secme ile NY'tan sececegim danscilari Istanbul'a bu projeye katmak amaciyla tasimak istiyorum.. Yanimda Istanbul'a goturmek istedigim NY'lu danscilarin ucuslarinin bir kismini, hem NY'ta hem Istanbul'da kalis masraflarimizin bir kismini karsilamak istiyorum en azindan bizim icin bir baslangic olucak bu butce. Agustos ayinda ayrica NY'tan bizi destekleyen kisiler icin ozel bir gosterim gerceklestiricez.. Daha sonra Ekim gibi Istanbul'da da yapilmasi planlanmaktadir.
    Bir yandan sponsorluklar aranmaya devam ederken bir yandan ayaklarimin uzerinde durup, sanatimla cagdas bir sekilde kendimi ifade etmeye devam edip, tecrubelerimi, ogrendiklerimi etrafimdakilerle paylasmaya devam edicem.

story:
Short Summary

Hello, Out There is Alyssa Keller's Directing Senior Project at SUNY Purchase College. She is a Senior Theatre and Performance/Arts Management double major with hopes of pursuing a career in Theatre Education. This will be the third show that Alyssa has directed at Purchase.

Hello, Out there is a hauntingly beautiful one act play written by William Saroyan. Set in 1942 Matador, Texas, we come to know the young man in the jail cell well. Upon the discovery that he was falsely accused of a crime, the audience as well as the young girl (who cooks for the jail) can't help but fall in love with him and hope for an escape from his already sealed fate.

Show Dates:  (All performances will be held in the Humanities Theater at SUNY Purchase)

Thursday, March 16th- 7:30pm

Friday, March 17th- 7:30pm

Saturday, March 18th- 2pm/7:30pm (There will be a cast talkback immediately following the 7:30pm performance on Saturday)

This production specifically will focus on the commentary of the Black Lives Matter Movement. It will comment on the fact that people were being falsely accused of crimes and were killed solely based on the color of their skin. How this was a common occurrence in 1942, and it still commonly occurs today in 2016. Despite everything, despite the fact that the main character knows how the play will end up, he remains hopeful for the future until the very end.

Cast:

The Young Man (Photo-Finish)- RJ Williams

The Girl- Kara DiResta

The Man- Derek Sherry

The Woman- Riley Stanzione

Second Man, Another Man, Third Man- Drew Burt, Brian Bowyer, Francesco Ciaramella

Production Team:

Director- Alyssa Keller

Assistant Director/Dramaturg- Sydney Frieberger

Stage Manager- Latyese McArthur

Set Designer- TBA

Technical Director- Deejay Lindo

Lighting Designer- Andrew Wehnke

Sound Designer- Danellys Wong

Costume Design- Virginia Edinger/Rosie Alston-Follansbee

Stage Combat Cordinator- Brian Bowyer

Videographer- Brandon Arroyo

What We Need & What You Get

You can check out the perks section to see what you will be receiving for your donations, but below is a basic outline of what our costs will look like:

Costumes- $400 (We've got to put period accurate clothing on 7-9 actors)

Advertisements- $50 (Printing is expensive)

Videography- $200 (We have a wonderful film student who will be filming promo videos as well as the actual performance and he deserves some compensation!)

Rights to the Show- $250 (Theatre is expensive)

Set- $1,100 (Wood, hardware, paint, furniture, props, prop gun +blanks, and we also need to build a movable, safe, sturdy jail cell that can be pieced together and taken apart with ease.)

The Impact

Your donation will be what makes the difference of us being able to afford putting 1940's era clothing on all of our actor's backs. It will make the difference of us being able to put a realistic looking, safe, and move-able jail cell onto the stage. Your donation will decide if this show can be good, or great.

Other Ways You Can Help

As broke college students, we recognize that all who wish to support may not necessarily be able to. Here are some other ways you can help that we would appreciate immensely:

  • Share the fundraising page! via twitter, facebook, e-mail, word of mouth, you name it, we'd love for you to share it with everyone you know.
  • Even if you can donate, simply sharing it will make a drastic difference in us being able to reach our goal.

story:
This July at the Center for Performance Research in Brooklyn, Virago Stage and Screen will debut Brooke Bell's satirical, feminist, multimedia performance piece the Dancing Boobies Trilogy: Lecture and Reenactments, which explores the nature of our patriarchal society's history of entitlement, desire, and expectation by parodying the mid-century and wholly American phenomenon of "stag films." As an intersectional feminist theatre and film company, Virago's mission is to bring fun, fierce, feminist art to all. Too often access to art is seen as a luxury that is afforded to those with privilege and pedigree rather than a cultural necessity. We need your help today to make Dancing Boobies FREE for anyone and everyone. Your donation will ensure that our artists are paid fairly, we can cover our production costs (space rental, costumes, lighting, props, etc.) and that those who cannot afford to donate themselves will be able to attend the show.


Show Description
Led by the egotistical artistic director Ekoorb Lleb, the struggling non-profit organization Women Who Tried To Change Our Lives (WWTCOL) is giving a lecture on Brooke Bell, an obscure performance/film artist active in the 1950's. Bell would disguise herself in drag and pose as a seller of stag films: then illegal pornographic shorts, primarily shot on 16mm film, that were made to be screened at so-called stag parties, where white, heterosexual men would gather to drink and smoke in excess without the presence of women. But the films that Bell would present to Ivy League fraternities and secret societies were a booby trap: Scenarios that seemed to begin with erotic promise would turn to an assault on the privilege these men held dear, accompanied with confrontational performances by Bell herself and followed by her quick exit, often effected while she was being pursued by a large group of angry and intoxicated men.
WWTCOL has unearthed the artist's rare 16mm film Dancing Boobies and has remade her two lost films Shaved Pussy (presumed destroyed after its screening at Yale University's Skull and Bones) and Penis Party (rumored to have been interred with Howard Hughes at Glenwood Cemetery), using today's digital technology. In addition to educating attendees on the political and aesthetic importance of these three works, WWTCOL curator/artistic director Lleb, art historian Melvin Master and film expert Paul Perv (all portrayed by women) will present them with live foley effects and performances Bell's notes had meticulously described. Interns Alice Askingforit, Betty Buns and Carla Cocktease (all portrayed by men wearing dresses over their street clothing) will be on hand to aid in these efforts and to document the audience's experience on a videotape that will be destroyed at the conclusion of the lecture and reenactments. Additionally, in order to create the full stag party context for which Bell's films were made, (empty) bottles of champagne and the finest (nonfunctional) cigars will be provided. Come and experience what those brothers of power, prestige, and privilege would have in the 1950's.

Show Information
8pm on July 8, 10. 15, and 17, at
The Center for Performance Research,
361 Manhattan Avenue, Unit 1
Brooklyn, New York 11211

story:
Joshua Harmon's Bad Jews is a groundbreaking dark comedy centered around family ties and the long term effects of the Holocaust on millennials.

We are producing "Bad Jews" at Purchase College SUNY and we need YOUR help to bring this incredible story to life.

Meet the Company:

Rob Reddington: Liam/co producer

Sydney Gottsman: Daphna

Michael Jorge: Jonah

Noelle Miller: Melody

Madison Hartke-Weber: director/co producer

Nic Mendez: stage manager

 

Performance Dates:

October 7 @ 7:30 pm
October 8 @ 2:30 pm
October 8 @ 7:30 pm

Location:
CCS Southside Lounge, SUNY Purchase College

We are raising funds costumes, props, and rights for the play. Every bit counts!

story:
THE SHAKESPEARE FORUM


New York is hard enough. We want to make it easier for everyone. At The Shakespeare Forum we make a home for actors, directors and lovers of Shakespeare to play, share, develop, and flourish. A community of artists dedicated to helping each other thrive while breaking the habits of isolationism which so often prevail in our artistic community. We believe that together we can be a powerful force and The Shakespeare Forum strives to provide its members with the tools to conquer this city, both as conscious artists and as parts of a greater artistic alliance.


Our Past.


The story of The Shakespeare Forum began with 4 people in a loft and a love of Shakespeare. The story developed as people from all walks of life found us and we, in turn, formed a community. Now, we need your help to share this community and all our stories with the rest of New York City. We have a season. We have a mission. Now we need to raise the money to make them both happen.


Our Future.


Our goal for the 2012 season is to:


1) Produce high quality productions of "Hamlet" and "A Midsummer Night's Dream" at a low cost to the NYC audience.


2) Reach out to, and perform/ teach in, at least 10 high need (Title 1) New York City Public Schools, with an emphasis on reaching schools in District 75.
District 75 provides citywide educational, vocational, and behavior support programs for students who are on the autism spectrum, have significant cognitive delays, are severely emotionally challenged, sensory impaired and/or multiply disabled (from schools.nyc.gov).


3) Provide New York actors and non-actors alike with workshops in which to promote dialogue and communication between seasoned professionals and novices in the acting profession.


How You Can Help:


  • We need to fund our Teaching Artists and The Shakespeare Forum Outreach Division.
  • We need money for production costs and actor stipends.
  • We need money to pay for our donation-based Tuesday night workshop space.

                                                                        AND
  • We desperately need a permanent space for The Shakespeare Forum to reside in. A space in which to work, rehearse, teach and welcome our ever-growing member base. If you are unable to support us financially, perhaps you can help us in this quest for a place to call home.




$10 (The Puck) provides 1/2 hour of rehearsal space.
$25 (The Rosalind) provides text materials for one school group.
$50 (The Don Armado) provides space for one workshop.
$100 (The Cleopatra) provides the salary for one teaching artist in a school visit.
$250 (The Claudius) provides a stipend for one actor.
$500 (The Orlando) provides one school with a visit from The Shakespeare Forum.
$1000 (The Benedick) provides for a production set.
$2500 (The Player King) provides for one week of performance space.
$5000 (The Henry V) provides performance space for a 2-week production.



**Special thanks** 
Alex Ricciardi of Endless Picnic for Editing and Color Correction
Adam Goodman and Daniel Hasse for videography     
and Music by Peculiar Gentlemen



Thank you in advance for your support!

story:
Whammy! goes to NYC

HotCity Theatre of St. Louis, and creator/director Chuck Harper, are damn happy to tell you that we are taking our orginal dance/theatre production of "Whammy! The Seven Secrets to a Sane Self" to the New York International Fringe Theatre Festival.  Chosen from over 800 applicants, "Whammy!" will be performed at the CSV Flamboyan Theatre on Manhattan's Lower East Side from August 15-24.

We are an ensemble of St. Louis-based theatre artists who are eager to show this unique and provocative production (premiered at HotCity in 2011) in our nation's theatre capital.  Your donation will provide transportation and housing for the cast and crew of eight during the fourteen days that they will be on the road and performing.  Performing in New York will be a dream come true for the Whammy! gang and we can't thank you enough for helping us to achieve this dream.

What We Need (and what you get!)

Although HotCity will be providing invaluable production and financial assistance (including rehearsal space, benefit performance venue, and marketing/staffing support) this project falls outside of our annual operating budgets and we need help to make it happen. We are raising a total of $9,000 for this event and our goal is raise $6,000 through Indiegogo (ie. you!).  The remainder of the budget will come from benefit performances and state grants.  Our needs are simple:

  • $2,500 for transportation (vehicle rental, fuel, etc.)
  • $4,000 for lodging (ten nights for eight people in NYC)
  • $2,500 for miscellaneous production costs (insurance, NYC personel, etc.)

HotCity Theatre will be providing the support we need to remount and produce the show including the following:

  • Rehearsal Space for the remount
  • Venue and staffing for benefit performances in St. Louis
  • Staffing and support for Columbus, Ohio benefit performance
  • Marketing and Publicity for the remount
  • Festival registration fees

Your donations will go directly to the travel and lodging needs of the cast and crew.  And should we surpass our goal?  We can start per diem stipends for the cast and crew!

We have a list of unique and Whammy!-appropriate perks on the page that we hope will give you that little extra nudge to do a donation-click.  They are all an expression of a very, very thankful group of theatre artists.  This is your chance at a limited-edition  Whammy! doodle by our scenic artist Mikey Butane Thomas.  Or a dvd of the NYC production along with special features of the cast and crew around the city and backstage.  Whatever you can donate will be greatly appreciated by team Whammy!

The Impact (ours and yours!)

As you already know if you have watched the video above (and for heaven's sake, please watch it if you haven't!) we feel that this is an entertaining and important piece of theatre that we are thrilled to be sharing with a wider audience.  We would like to think that, in our own quirky way, we are contributing to a saner society.  And your donation means that you are doing the same.

The artists involved in this project have a proven record of succesful national and international projects of this nature.  Chuck Harper (creator/director) has had his work produced in the US from Los Angeles to Chicago (but not yet NYC!) and in Europe in France, Germany and the Czech Republic.  He has received local, state and national grants including the NEA's ArtsLink International Partners grant.  Mikey Butane Thomas has seen his dances and movement activities performed around the US and in Taipei and Toronto as well.   This project will be a milestone for all the artists on team Whammy! as we bring our newest, and craziest, project to the biggest stage of all. 

You Love Us But Times are Tight?

If you are unable to donate at this time, we still love you, and we still need your help.  Here's what you can do:

  • Tell your friends and family to check us out and make a donation.  (Really, you can kind of claim credit for these funds) 
  • If you live in St. Louis or Columbus, tell your friends and family to check out our website and to make a reservation for the benefit performance parties
  • If you live in New York, come see the show!  More info to follow on performance dates.
story_txt:
Whammy! goes to NYC
HotCity Theatre of St. Louis, and creator/director Chuck Harper, are damn happy to tell you that we are taking our orginal dance/theatre production of "Whammy! The Seven Secrets to a Sane Self" to the New York International Fringe Theatre Festival.  Chosen from over 800 applicants, "Whammy!" will be performed at the CSV Flamboyan Theatre on Manhattan's Lower East Side from August 15-24.
We are an ensemble of St. Louis-based theatre artists who are eager to show this unique and provocative production (premiered at HotCity in 2011) in our nation's theatre capital.  Your donation will provide transportation and housing for the cast and crew of eight during the fourteen days that they will be on the road and performing.  Performing in New York will be a dream come true for the Whammy! gang and we can't thank you enough for helping us to achieve this dream.

What We Need (and what you get!)
Although HotCity will be providing invaluable production and financial assistance (including rehearsal space, benefit performance venue, and marketing/staffing support) this project falls outside of our annual operating budgets and we need help to make it happen. We are raising a total of $9,000 for this event and our goal is raise $6,000 through Indiegogo (ie. you!).  The remainder of the budget will come from benefit performances and state grants.  Our needs are simple:

$2,500 for transportation (vehicle rental, fuel, etc.)
$4,000 for lodging (ten nights for eight people in NYC)
$2,500 for miscellaneous production costs (insurance, NYC personel, etc.)

HotCity Theatre will be providing the support we need to remount and produce the show including the following:

Rehearsal Space for the remount
Venue and staffing for benefit performances in St. Louis
Staffing and support for Columbus, Ohio benefit performance
Marketing and Publicity for the remount
Festival registration fees

Your donations will go directly to the travel and lodging needs of the cast and crew.  And should we surpass our goal?  We can start per diem stipends for the cast and crew!
We have a list of unique and Whammy!-appropriate perks on the page that we hope will give you that little extra nudge to do a donation-click.  They are all an expression of a very, very thankful group of theatre artists.  This is your chance at a limited-edition  Whammy! doodle by our scenic artist Mikey Butane Thomas.  Or a dvd of the NYC production along with special features of the cast and crew around the city and backstage.  Whatever you can donate will be greatly appreciated by team Whammy!

You Love Us But Times are Tight?
If you are unable to donate at this time, we still love you, and we still need your help.  Here's what you can do:

Tell your friends and family to check us out and make a donation.  (Really, you can kind of claim credit for these funds) 
If you live in St. Louis or Columbus, tell your friends and family to check out our website and to make a reservation for the benefit performance parties
If you live in New York, come see the show!  More info to follow on performance dates.

story:
Short Summary

Life is like rain.  We all experience it.  Sometimes it can be violent and tragic, leaving scars that never heal... or as peaceful as the morning dew. 

The story of "RAIN," uses the symbolism to parallel the lives of Matthew Carpenter and Renee Marshall - two people with tragic pasts, both on different pathways of destruction.  Until they meet on the road to redemption, and everything changes.

RAIN is unlike anything you have ever experienced in a theatrical production!  The story will captivate you with gut-wrenching sorrow, and relieve you with moments of great joy, followed by a powerful dose of inspiration!

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our intention is to tour with this production, reaching as many people in as many cities as possible throughout 2014/2015, so honestly, the more money we raise, the more we will be able to accomplish this goal.

We are pros at stretching our dollars and relying upon in-kind material donations and volunteers, but that only goes so far without financial support.  

Initially, we need $25,000 to help pay for theatre rental, rehearsal space, set build out, marketing and promotion needs, small stipend for actors and crew, and some travel costs.

In return for your support, we are offering some incredible (and I do mean INCREDIBLE) perks that you can display proudly and remember "RAIN - the Experience" and how your generous financial seed impacted communities around the country.

Check out the perks for more detail.

Should we not meet our initial $25,000 goal, whatever amount we do raise will be a tremendous help in getting us started.  We do have some private investors who are waiting to see how much money we DO raise on our own, and they will contribute once we have the pre-production well underway.  

So, not only are you supporting a very unique and worthy production, making a difference in people's lives, and creating an experience for audiences around the country, you are building support by others who have interest in RAIN!  

Your gift, no matter the size, is the gift that keeps on giving! 

 

The Impact

Dealing with adult themes such as HIV/AIDS, domestic violence, and death, RAIN takes the audience on a faith-filled voyage of emotions and gives voice to people imprisoned by hidden secrets.  

In the end, the audience will be mesmerized and moved by the impeccable drama and inspirational story of redemption.

Supporting this campaign will provide a powerful community outreach that extends beyond a play.  This production is designed to be a tool to help hurting people impacted by tragedy and trauma, abuse, terminal illness, depression, suicide, financial distress, and other emotional or physical issues.

Resources will be made available at the end of the play to help those in need or at-risk, and your financial support will make this all possible!

Written and produced by Leo Pacheco, who is an author, founder of 3 faith-based non-profit organizations, a successful business consultant, and recognized by several awards and accolades for his community outreach efforts, Leo's passion for hurting people is what inspired him to create RAIN.

"Aside from my personal storms in life, I have had the difficult challenge of serving as a grief counselor to people who are really struggling with life," Leo says, "And RAIN gives voice to those who don't know how to put their pain into words."

But, RAIN isn't all about pain and suffering.  It has an inspirational story to tell!

Leo says, "We don't want to take the audience to a dark place and leave them there.  We want to offer hope that there is light at the end of the darkness, and they can be set free from the storms they face.  That's what RAIN is all about - hope and redemption."

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot support financially, you may know others who can.  But, there are other ways you can help make an impact with RAIN.  Here are just a few:

  • PRAY - Pray for peace, deliverance from the pain, and for life-changing impacts to be felt everywhere we go.

 

  • PROMOTION - Word of mouth is the cheapest, yet most valuable, form of marketing.  We don't have to pay for it, yet it is priceless!  After all, promoting something you believe in will excite and engage others to do the same, so helping promote RAIN is far more valuable than often money can buy.  Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools and spread the word via social media.

 

  • VOLUNTEER - Giving of your time and expertise is worth a ton!  Volunteers help keep the overhead down and provide us more bang for our supporters' bucks!  So, if you have a talent or expertise, don't be afraid to inquire about helping us out!  You never know how beneficial this can be.

 

  • FUNDRAISE - You may not have a large bank account, but you may know someone who does.  Or simply gathering a few friends who each contribute what they can, adds up greatly!  Or have a party where you invite us to come over and give potential donors a preview of RAIN so your friends know what they are contributing to.  After all, who wouldn't want a semi-pro actor as a special guest?  He or she may be the next Meryl Streep or Hugh Jackman!  And you had them at your party first!

 

For more information, please visit www.LIONSCRESTGROUP.com or www.Experience-Rain.com

story:
Cloud Dance Festival: Lacuna - 5-7 July 2013, Bernie Grant Arts Centre

Cloud Dance Festival was created in 2007, and Lacuna was our 13th festival to date. It is a a showcase designed to promote the best in new and emerging talent in contemporary dance and ballet, focussing on unfunded artists with the goal of helping them to develop their careers.

Cloud Dance Festival always had one aim from the outset: to serve as an example of what could be achieved without funding, initially relying only on our ticket sales for our income. Even in 2008 and 2009, it was rewarding to produce a successful and critically-acclaimed platform with high production values while covering its own costs - but that only lasted so long!

The other aims of Cloud Dance Festival are what it's best known for:

  • presenting showcases of the most promising and talented artists in contemporary dance and contemporary ballet
  • strategically reaching new audiences by making both dance styles more accessible to potential audiences.



As our budget has always been limited, we've striven to make the festival the best possible experience for all participants, by selecting good dance venues and selecting highly-skilled lighting, stage, photography and video staff to provide them with full production and marketing support, ample photography, video footage, reviews and industry connections to assist them with their future work.

We've also provided ongoing support for our past participants in everything from general advice and assistance to mentoring and artistic management.

We're very proud of our past participants: past applicants have included Drew McOnie, Gerrard Martin, Hagit Yakira, James Wilton, Joss Arnott, Slanjayvah Danza (Leeds) and taciturn (Liverpool) while past special guests have included Ballet Black, Dam Van Huynh, Devaraj Thimmaiah, Jonathan Goddard & Gemma Nixon, James Cousins, Jarkko Lehmus, Kristen McNally, Tommy Franzén and Mavin Khoo.

In addition to supporting and developing choreographers, we also have schemes to mentor emerging dance writers and photographers at each festival, while our volunteers have gone on to very successful careers in the dance industry.


So this is where you come in.

All of this costs a lot to achieve, and until now, our only sources of income have been a nominal participation fee charged to each company, and the income from ticket sales, which has never allowed us to plan beyond covering our core costs.

We had arranged a box office split with Bernie Grant Arts Centre for our festival, but because of issues experienced with the box office, we urgently need to raise extra funds to ensure we can pay our staff, who contributed significantly to the festival's success.

We had wanted to use the box office proceeds to support the artists participating in the festival, but that is no longer possible now.

This means we need your support to help cover the following costs:

  • £450 for our lighting designer, Nic Holdridge
  • £80 for Nic's digs nearby so that he didn't have to spend 4 hours each day commuting back and forth
  • £300 for our assistant stage managers - the best ones we've ever had!
  • £300 for our dance photographer, Camilla Greenwell
  • £300 for our video editor to produce high-quality documentation for all participating artists, including edited full-length footage and edited highlights
  • I'd really like to get paid too, after working flat out on the festival for a month, but ensuring that everyone else has been paid is far more important.
  • (our wonderful stage manager, Cat Harmer, has already been paid from the proceeds of the first crowdfunding campaign)


The Impact

The strength of Cloud Dance Festival has always been its independence and the support it provides its artists, so after a two-year break, we want to make the most of our return by going beyond what we've offered in the past, and taking the first steps towards creating a more tangible legacy.

Although our core costs exceed the target amount of this campaign, we're aware that this is not an economically healthy time for crowdfunding, so we'd rather ask for a more realistic amount and be extremely grateful for all the pledges we receive, especially should they exceed our set target.


Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everybody can contribute towards our campaign, so the most important thing you can do to help us is to spread the word, to anyone you think might be interested in our work and supportive of it. We need people to talk about our work!

Do you know someone or a company who might be interested in sponsoring the work we do or the support we provide, or who might be interested in forming a partnership? We'd be extremely grateful if you could put them in touch with us.

And thank you so so much for your interest and for reading this far!

story:
Our Story:

WHY GLITTER BEACH?

When Vicky Hamilton (legendary rock manager, A&R person and writer) www.vickyhamilton.com:and Robbie Quine (quintessential glam rock cult hero, surfer, musician and writer)www.myspace.com/theofficalbarbarellatones got together in 2007 to write Glitter Beach they talked about their favorite plays and what they themselves would pay to see. They embarked on an undertaking of writing a musical that took Rocky Horror with a side of Hedwig and The Angry Inch added some sexy Glam Rock music ala David Bowie and took it to the beach. When they finished, they knew they had something fun, imaginative and special.

In 2010 Hamilton stalked Hollywood "It" boy director Daniel Henning www.theblank.com and begged him to take a look at the first draft. Henning agreed it could be special if it was rewritten and set in 1967. So under Henning, Hamilton and Quine rewrote the musical and had their first reading at The Blank Theatre in March 2011. It was a sold out success! 

NOW WE NEED YOUR HELP TO TAKE GLITTER BEACH TO THE NEXT LEVEL so Glitter Beach can see the light of day and hit stages around the globe,  bringing misfits, bullies, mermaids, glam rockers, and surfers together everywhere for a magical night of fun! Other goals include helping the Surfrider Foundation, save our oceans and beaches.  

GLITTER BEACH AND THE SURF RIDER FOUNDATION TEAM UP TO MAKE THE WORLD A BETTER PLACE.

5% of all donations to Glitter Beach will be given to the Surf Rider Foundation to save or oceans and beaches.
for more info on Surfrider Foundation  www.surfrider.org

Glitter Beach's  Chapter is:

SURFRIDER FOUNDATION â€“ WEST LA / MALIBU CHAPTER
Surfrider Foundation is a volunteer based non-profit environmental grassroots organization dedicated to the protection and enjoyment of our worldâ€™s oceans, waves and beaches for all people, through conservation, activism, research and education. The West LA/Malibu Chapter represents 31 miles of coastline from Ballona Creek to LA county line and inland. Become a Member Today!
www.surfriderwlam.org


 A brief synopsis of GLITTER BEACH the musical play:

Itâ€™s 1967 and itâ€™s all happeningâ€¦hot surfers, beach bunnies, muscle men, mermaids, sex wax and trannies on Glitter Beach, where glam began.  Glitter Beach invites you to ride the waves with androgynous surfer Reef Bedrock as he follows his rock and roll dreamsâ€¦ so grab your leopard surf board and glitter guitar and take a wild ride with us!

This fabulous musical combines the sensibilities of Priscilla Queen of the Desert and The Rocky Horror Picture Show with Beach Blanket Bingo! Cowabunga, bitch!

 


The Impact

Aren't you tired of seeing the same old thing? Glitter Beach is fresh, fun and spiritual! It tells the world that is is OK to be different! Celebrate your uniqueness! Also Glitter Beach is committed to helping our beaches stay beautiful! Once the play has moved to productions in other cities Surfrider will support us through all their chapters...What could be a better than that!  Support the arts and keep your beaches beautiful!



What We Need & What You Get

The money we raise here will go towards a $100,000 fund we need to do a week of musical play workshops for theatre producers in Los Angeles.

This money will go towards renting a venue, building props, paying actors, musicians, rehearsal and advertising, putting together and printing a great producer package, including cast recordings of all the songs (you can hear roughs of the showtunes on Vicky's website www.vickyhamilton.com click musical play and it is up on a Soundcloud)

If we are unsuccessful in raising the full amount to do the workshops, we will use the money to finish the recordings, and making beautiful producer packages to solicited private investors and producers until we have enough to do the workshops and fulfill our Glitter Beach dream!  We will not stop until there is a production of Glitter Beach everywhere!


Other Ways You Can Help

SPREAD THE WORD!!!
Please send a link to this campaign to anyone who you think might be interested to help us make our glam rock surf musical dream come true. Sign up to our Facebook page http://www.facebook.com/GlitterBeachMusical help us build the Glitter Beach army and we will give you updates and keep you posted to our progress.

If you have any ideas of how we can get press exposure or put the project in the hands of producers who can help, we would love to hear from you!  You can write to Vicky at tototunes2@aol.com

This money will go towards renting a venue, building props, paying actors, musicians, rehearsal and advertising, putting together and printing a great producer package, including cast recordings of all the songs (you can hear roughs of the showtunes on Vicky's website www.vickyhamilton.com click musical play and it is up on a Soundcloud)

If we are unsuccessful in raising the full amount to do the workshops, we will use the money to finish the recordings, and making beautiful producer packages to solicited private investors and producers until we have enough to do the workshops and fulfill our Glitter Beach dream!  We will not stop until there is a production of Glitter Beach everywhere!


Other Ways You Can Help
SPREAD THE WORD!!!

Please send a link to this campaign to anyone who you think might be interested to help us make our glam rock surf musical dream come true. Sign up to our Facebook page http://www.facebook.com/GlitterBeachMusical help us build the Glitter Beach army and we will give you updates and keep you posted to our progress.


If you have any ideas of how we can get press exposure or put the project in the hands of producers who can help, we would love to hear from you!  You can write to Vicky at tototunes2@aol.com

story:
Exit Pursued by a Bear is a local grassroots theatre company.  We strive to give members of the community a unique chance to experience a wide range of artistic experiences: directing, acting, building, and having free access to classical theatre.  We firmly believe that theatre should be accessible to the public and want to share its magic to everyone. 

Tyler and Kristie Lopez founded Exit Pursued by a Bear which to date has produced over 10 full-length shows in a variety of found spaces, studios, and parks—turning the ordinary into extraordinary.  This September, the company hopes to produce free repertory productions of William Shakespeare’s Julius Caesar and Measure for Measure.

Exit Pursued by a Bear has been a tool for building relationships and unity in the Central Coast community.  Your help would keep this bond of community, artistic fulfillment, and the spirit of theatre alive and growing for the Central Coast of California!

 


    …

    Our goal is to raise $1200 for the production of our two shows.  Nearly the entirety of this sum will be going into securing our performance venues by paying the requisite fees involved in renting the parks, obtaining the proper permits and purchasing the necessary insurance.  The rest will go into much needed repairs of our set as well as the purchase of other set and costume pieces for the productions, as well as advertising the shows. More than this amount will ultimately be spent on these productions this is just the amount that would allow us to be confident in our ability to cover the rest.


     

    If you would like to help us in ways other than donating, please spread the word about our cause and fundraiser!  Let’s tell our friends and share our information on facebook to help the community! Together, we can make this happen! 

     

    You can find Exit Pursued by a Bear’s facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/exitpursuedbyabeartheatre.  Please comment and share!  The more we can share our art and our cause, the more peoples’ lives we can enrich!  Thank you for your support!

story:
English description

Bad Orb's opera academy is a unique initiative that facilitates young singers to gain stage experience.

Every year an opera in total is performed with numerous young singers from all around the world applying for it. For many of them the academy already served as a springboard for further engagements in large opera houses.

A production itself costs about 70.000 € of which 35.000 € have to be acquired by contributions. This becomes more difficult every year. Hence, we would appreciate if you supported our unique project and thus also supported young singers.

Kurzbeschreibung

Die Opernakademie Bad Orb, eine in der Bundesrepublik wohl einmalige kulturelle Bürgerinitiative, fördert seit vielen Jahren sehr erfolgreich den internationalen Sängernachwuchs für die Opernbühne. 

Kontinuierlich, ehrlich und zielorientiert gibt die Opernakademie jungen Sängerinnen und Sängern die hervorragende Chance, sich unter professioneller Anleitung durch die Einstudierung und Aufführung einer kompletten Oper auf den schwierigen Bühnenberuf vorzubereiten. Jährlich werden aus hunderten von Bewerberinnen und Bewerbern die Solistinnen und Solisten für die einzelnen Produktionen ausgewählt.

Seit 1987 haben junge Vokalistinnen und Vokalisten aus zahlreichen Ländern rund um den Globus dieses Angebot genutzt. Für viele junge Nachwuchskräfte ist die Opernakademie Bad Orb zum Sprungbrett auf die Bühnen namhafter Opernhäuser geworden.


Die Bad Orber Opernaufführungen sind weit über Hessen bekannt und geschätzt. Eine regelmäßige, rundweg positive Berichterstattung in Rundfunk, Fernsehen, Fachmedien sowie in regionaler und überregionaler Tagespresse trägt zum guten Ruf der Opernakademie und ihrer Produktionen wesentlich bei. Gerade weil in Bad Orb die Bühnenwerke auf deutsch gesungen und in „wiedererkennbarem“ Gewand gezeigt werden, kann die Akademie auf einen langjährigen treuen Besucherkreis bauen – die Basis der Opernakademie.

Der enorme und beispielhafte Einsatz des Fördervereins und der örtlichen Bevölkerung hat zu einer hohen Identifikation beigetragen, ohne die die Arbeit der Opernakademie nicht möglich wäre. Viele Bürgerinnen und Bürger engagieren sich sehr intensiv und schaffen damit die Basis für die Produktionen. 

Dank ihrer ständig wachsenden Bekanntheit sowie wegen ihres regionalen und überregionalen Renommees bietet die Opernakademie Sponsoren eine viel versprechende Plattform, um ihr Unternehmen in die kulturelle Förderung nachhaltig und erfolgreich einzubringen.



Was wir brauchen & Was man bekommt

Eine Opernproduktion kostet rund 70 000 Euro. Abzüglich der Einnahmen aus dem Kartenverkauf und der Sponsorengelder bleibt ein Minus von 35.000 Euro, das abgedeckt werden muss. Deshalb werben wir auf diesem Wege für unsere Produktionen, zumal es von Jahr zu Jahr schwieriger wird, Sponsoren zu finden.


Andere Wege, wie man helfen kann

Wenn Sie der Opernakademie andersweitig helfen möchten, machen Sie doch einfach Folgendes:

  • Empfehlen Sie die Indiegogo-Seite (http://igg.me/opernakademie).
  • Stellen Sie ein Zimmer/eine Wohnung einem jungen Künstler zur Verfügung. Einige Musikerinnen und Musiker benötigen eine Unterkunft für ca. 10 Tage, einige Sängerinnen und Sänger für 4-5 Wochen.
  • werben Sie in Ihrem Freundes- und Bekanntenkreis für eine Mitgliedschaft im Förderverein.
  • werben Sie für unsere Aufführungen, die seit Jahrzehnten das Publikum immer wieder begeistert haben.

story:
Are you I.N.?

Industry Night is coming! It's an old-school variety show done BY the Austin Arts & Entertainment Industry, FOR the Austin Arts & Entertainment Industry. For many of us who work in the Industry, Monday night is the only night we all have off.  So for all four Mondays in July (7th, 14th, 21st, & 28th) at the North Door in East Austin, we are throwing a show for us - by us.

  • This is also a show for the people of Austin who support the arts; the audience, the patrons, the people who love the Austin arts scene and appreciate the great talent this city has to offer.

There will be Industry folks. There will be drinks, and drink SPECIALS! There will be skits, music, film, dance, comedy and so much more. Afterwards (for those who are down) there will be Karaoke and PRIZES! If you are I.N. the industry (or know someone who is), you are I.N. at Industry Night!

  • Industry Night is brought to you by: Chris Gibson, Michelle Keffer, Rocky Hopson, Cami Alys, Kenny Redding Jr., Jeff Mills, Jessie Douglas, Lowell Bartholomee, David Higgins, Jason Newman, Brock England and many more! 
  • Guests include: Graham Reynolds, Buzz Moran, Devolver, Salvage Vanguard Theatre, Minnow Mountain, Schaive & Reilly, Glass Half-Full Theatre, Trouble Puppet Theatre,  The Dionysium, Jason Phelps, and many, many more! 

This is a night for us, by us - tech crew, costumers, carpenters, management teams, performers, directors and producers - we've all dedicated our lives to this "business we call show." Come let Us show You a good time - at Industry Night!

What We Need & What You Get

  • Industry Night is a true Labour of Love. Everyone is donating their valuable time and extraordinary talents to make this show happen. However, there are still expenses. A lot of 'em. Venue Rental. Equipment. Marketing. The Human Cannon. It gets pricey. (we'll probably cut the Human Cannon, but still) We can make it all happen without losing our shirts in the process, for $4000 - but we need your help!
  • We at Industry Night believe that sometimes, in business, you have to offer things in order to receive things in return. So... WE are here to offer YOU... Perks. Juicy perks. Perks that can put you ONSTAGE! (or not, if you're not into that) Become a producer,  advertise your business, come up and be part of the show, or just get your tickets in advance. Whatever you can contribute will help us make our little dream of a variety show come true. We are truly grateful for your generosity. 

The Impact

We are creating four unique shows in one month! Inspired by the great variety shows like The Dean Martin Show, Ed Sullivan, and the Muppets, we will showcase some of the best of the Austin Arts & Entertainment Industry and create our own original content as well.

And Get This

Each episode will be performed and recorded live, and then edited and posted on the web within a day or two of the show. 

We want to create a lasting record of, and a tribute to, those of us working in the Austin Arts & Entertainment Industry, here and now in 2014. If it's a success, we may decide to do it every summer!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about Industry Night.
  • Propagate, ya'll! Don't forget about the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
Help us get POSH onto stages in San Francisco and New York!

foolsFURY is working on our juiciest, most ambitious project ever! This play is the result of our long artistic exploration into collaborative creation - working with amazing artists all over the country.

Climb aboard the luxury cruise ship Crown of the Seas, and join an eclectic group of seekers as they strive for enlightenment. Amidst the sensual decadence of bars, discos, and gluttonous buffets, they un-tether themselves from the baggage of their everyday lives and become entangled in a strange, disturbing ritual. Sit right back and take a surreal journey the folks at Princess Cruises never imagined in their wildest dreams.

We've gone way out on a financial limb to produce this collaboration with kick-ass celebrated playwright Sheila Callaghan, co-produced with Z Space in San Francisco and La Mama in New York. We need your help to make it what it deserves to be!  

 

What We Need & What You Get

Your donation will help us pay for materials, rehearsal space, artists, technicians, and travel between San Francisco and New York.  Every bit helps!

We have perishable props onstage that your $25 donation will sponsor.  We have over dozens of actors and artists working on POSH - your donations from $250 to $1000 will directly pay for their fees and budgets.  Any amount will help offset travel and building costs!

The Impact

foolsFURY is a multi-award winning ensemble theater based in San Francisco, dedicated to creating ground-breaking visceral performances that inspire audiences and artists to reconsider and reconnect with the world around them. Your donation will get our biggest production onto stage on both coasts, and give us support and energy to produce work after 2012, and keep redefining the way live theater is made!

Future productions:

The FURY Factory, showcasing ensemble theaters from across the country and abroad.

Awesome plays: THE UNHEARD OF WORLD and (r)EVOLUTION X - for more details visit http://foolsfury.org/fury/indevelopment/

 

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to a donation, you can also help us spread the word!  Please share our campaign and come see the show in San Francisco (10 performances; September 7-22) and New York (November 10-25)!

Buy tickets to Port Out, Starboard Home at www.foolsfury.org!

Video by Dean Mermell
www.storyfarm.com

story:
Thank you, your help is appreciated

       When I was a little girl, I was incredibly shy.  I use to hide behind my mother’s legs whenever strangers and even family members were around.  Despite being so timid, I had dreams of being a singer and an actress.  At the age of 12, my best friend at the time convinced me to join a theatre class at our middle school the following school year.  After my first day in the class, I realized that I had found my calling, but the only thing holding me back was stage fright.  While I waited in the wings before I was to step out onto the stage for the first time, I felt butterflies in my stomach.  It was not out of nervousness one might assume, but excitement.  The curtain rose, the lights came up, and it was then that I realized this was where I wanted to be for the rest of my life.  I broke out of my shell that night, October 22, 2004. 

 

Here are some examples of my singing in  Musical Theatre:

Jac Sickels (Emma) & I (Lucy) singing 'In His Eyes- Jekell & Hyde' in our Musical Theatre Voice final.http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HK7fZpVZIrE …

 

"Deep Love" from Young Frankenstein  
My Musical #Theatre Voice 1 final at UCF 2013  http://youtu.be/lElFhIHHIjY

 

My Cover of "Don't Forget Me" from ''Smash" - http://youtu.be/sppfGr8QVp4

 

       Theatre is my escape from reality and my therapy.  I was raised by a single mom who worked hard to provide for my brother and me.  As soon as I was able to get a job, I did so I could help pay bills.  When I was 19, I moved to Orlando to attend the University of Central Florida to major in Theatre Studies.  I work as much as I can to pay for bills and food, and my mom helps me the best she can from Miami.  I go to school full-time, work part-time, and perform in shows if my availability allows.  

 

Some of the shows I've performed in include Man of La Mancha, High School Musical, Rent, Godspell, Seussical, Beauty & the Beast and Jekyll & Hyde


Here is my resume

        Back in October 2012, the Producing Artistic Director, Bruce Earnest, came to UCF to host a Belting Workshop in the Theatre Building.  He told us about International Performing Arts Institute (IPAI) and the Musical Theatre program.  Those interested in the program could use participation  in the workshop as our audition into the program.   Only 20 students in the U.S. are accepted from the thousands that apply & audition.  I received an email about a week later from Bruce offering me a spot in the Musical Theatre program.  It is a 3 week intensive program in Germany this summer (July 7-28).  I will be up there for my birthday.

       Many students that attend the program get picked up to do professional shows in Europe with StageEntertainment.  Mr Earnest told me that I am very marketable in Europe with my looks and talent.  This is a very big opportunity for me because Europe likes fresh faces.  I have been given an opportunity of a lifetime, but the only thing that is hindering me is money.  With your help, I can take the first step in making my dreams come true.  Whatever you can give will help tremendously and even if you can’t, tell people who you know can.  Thank you for taking the time to view my campaign.

 Tuition is $5225 plus whatever transportation to the program (airfare, transportation from airport to location).  

 

For more information, check out the website at:

http://internationalperformingartsinstitute.com/

 

International Performing Arts Institute (IPAI) offers professional training in both musical theatre and opera from artists from all over the world. The primary goal of IPAI is to help people realize their full potential as a singer-actor in an environment that nurtures their creativity while offering real-life opportunities for artistic employment in Europe.
 
The IPAI Musical Theatre Program includes Musical Theatre Intensives in Hamburg, Germany where participants work with casting directors from Stage Entertainment, the largest producer of musicals in Europe.  The European Musical Theate Audition Program is also located in Hamburg, Germany and is hosted by the Joop Van den Ende Academy in coordination with Stage Entertainment.
 
Housing and transportation for the Musical Theatre Intensive in Hamburg are included.  Students experience the opportunity to work with choreographers, casting agents and voice teachers along with students who are currently performing in shows such as Wicked, Lion King, Mama Mia, Elton John's Aida and Dirty Dancing.  IPAI participants will have the opportunity to attend a show, and if applicable, audition for Stage Entertainment.

 

This is what I need to get me there and how I can thank you

  • Tuition fees for the course is $5225 plus whatever transportation to the program (airfare, transportation from airport to location).
  • For a contribution to my future my wonderful donors will be thanked with various perks ranging from social thanks , A video thank you, a personal postcard sent to you from Germany, me singing you a song of your choice, my promoton of your project or company, a photomosaic with your image or avatar and finally for those who can get themselves to Germnay at the time, a tour with me of the Interntonal Performing Arts Institute

 

How much your help will impact my life

This course acceptance is huge to me. Not only am I so lucky to have been picked, but this could well open the door to working for Stage Entertainment and the global production opportunities that could therefore follow.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate at this time but would still like to help

Please let your friends know about my campaign by social media, phone, email

Please use the Indiegogo share tools on this page

Jac Sickels (Emma) & I (Lucy) singing 'In His Eyes- Jekell & Hyde' in our Musical Theatre Voice final.http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HK7fZpVZIrE …
 
"Deep Love" from Young Frankenstein   My Musical #Theatre Voice 1 final at UCF 2013  http://youtu.be/lElFhIHHIjY
 
My Cover of "Don't Forget Me" from ''Smash" - http://youtu.be/sppfGr8QVp4 
 
       Theatre is my escape from reality and my therapy.  I was raised by a single mom who worked hard to provide for my brother and me.  As soon as I was able to get a job, I did so I could help pay bills.  When I was 19, I moved to Orlando to attend the University of Central Florida to major in Theatre Studies.  I work as much as I can to pay for bills and food, and my mom helps me the best she can from Miami.  I go to school full-time, work part-time, and perform in shows if my availability allows.  
 
Some of the shows I've performed in include Man of La Mancha, High School Musical, Rent, Godspell, Seussical, Beauty & the Beast and Jekyll & Hyde
Here is my resume 
        Back in October 2012, the Producing Artistic Director, Bruce Earnest, came to UCF to host a Belting Workshop in the Theatre Building.  He told us about International Performing Arts Institute (IPAI) and the Musical Theatre program.  Those interested in the program could use participation  in the workshop as our audition into the program.   Only 20 students in the U.S. are accepted from the thousands that apply & audition.  I received an email about a week later from Bruce offering me a spot in the Musical Theatre program.  It is a 3 week intensive program in Germany this summer (July 7-28).  I will be up there for my birthday.
       Many students that attend the program get picked up to do professional shows in Europe with StageEntertainment.  Mr Earnest told me that I am very marketable in Europe with my looks and talent.  This is a very big opportunity for me because Europe likes fresh faces.  I have been given an opportunity of a lifetime, but the only thing that is hindering me is money.  With your help, I can take the first step in making my dreams come true.  Whatever you can give will help tremendously and even if you can’t, tell people who you know can.  Thank you for taking the time to view my campaign.
 Tuition is $5225 plus whatever transportation to the program (airfare, transportation from airport to location).  
 
For more information, check out the website at:
http://internationalperformingartsinstitute.com/
 
International Performing Arts Institute (IPAI) offers professional training in both musical theatre and opera from artists from all over the world. The primary goal of IPAI is to help people realize their full potential as a singer-actor in an environment that nurtures their creativity while offering real-life opportunities for artistic employment in Europe.
 
The IPAI Musical Theatre Program includes Musical Theatre Intensives in Hamburg, Germany where participants work with casting directors from Stage Entertainment, the largest producer of musicals in Europe.  The European Musical Theate Audition Program is also located in Hamburg, Germany and is hosted by the Joop Van den Ende Academy in coordination with Stage Entertainment.
 
Housing and transportation for the Musical Theatre Intensive in Hamburg are included.  Students experience the opportunity to work with choreographers, casting agents and voice teachers along with students who are currently performing in shows such as Wicked, Lion King, Mama Mia, Elton John's Aida and Dirty Dancing.  IPAI participants will have the opportunity to attend a show, and if applicable, audition for Stage Entertainment.
 

This is what I need to get me there and how I can thank you

Tuition fees for the course is $5225 plus whatever transportation to the program (airfare, transportation from airport to location).
For a contribution to my future my wonderful donors will be thanked with various perks ranging from social thanks , A video thank you, a personal postcard sent to you from Germany, me singing you a song of your choice, my promoton of your project or company, a photomosaic with your image or avatar and finally for those who can get themselves to Germnay at the time, a tour with me of the Interntonal Performing Arts Institute

 


How much your help will impact my life
This course acceptance is huge to me. Not only am I so lucky to have been picked, but this could well open the door to working for Stage Entertainment and the global production opportunities that could therefore follow.
 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to donate at this time but would still like to help
Please let your friends know about my campaign by social media, phone, email
Please use the Indiegogo share tools on this page

story:
Hi All!

Aleya here (in Cairo) I am so excited to present a brand new, amazing project to you. I can’t wait till it’s all up and running and you can finally take belly dance classes and folkloric classes online with teachers from Cairo!  I’m trying to launch by Feb. 2014.  Just in time for my birthday and Valentines Day and it will be a great gift to myself for you all to be able to take classes online with all of the best teachers in Cairo.  I know it’s difficult to come to Cairo with the expense and political upheaval, but now, from the privacy of your own home you can come to Cairo and study with your favorite teachers! This is a big, ground breaking project and it has taken some time to get everything right, but I still need your help to launch and I hope you all can contribute to this fantastic project.  I have wanted to do this project for well over 10 years but when I conceived of the idea the technology was not even available and now that it has caught up with my dream I started,  and now there is no going back! :) 

I have been living in Egypt for the past 5 years performing, teaching, travelling the world teaching,  learning from many master teachers, and selling beautiful costumes.  I lived through a revolution, which has still not ended and have experienced wonderful and incredible things that belly dance has brought to my life.  Also, during this time I have had the honor to take class with all of the amazing teachers at the festivals and privately.   It has been an invaluable learning experience for me and I would love to be able to share that with you and the world.   

What is Cairobellydance.com?

This is going to be a website where you can actually take classes from teachers in Cairo online.  Many will be full choreographies and some will be technique, or teaching you how to improvise or even just the basics.  Most of the teachers have been dancing for 20-30+ years and I will also have foreigners who have lived and worked in Cairo absorbing the culture and the nuances of the dance.  Eventually, I would love this to be your GO TO resource for all things related to belly dance and folklore dance in the Middle East.  Costumes, music, what’s happening in Cairo, blogs.  I would like this to be one big portal to the Middle East where you can just push on one button and all of it will be at your fingertips!

Why is this important?

From costumes, to music, to choreographies and history I am certain this will be an invaluable tool for your training and ongoing study of belly dance and folkloric dance from the Middle East. We learn dance from so many teachers, but I believe you never can fully grasp the concept of Oriental dance unless you have access to study with master teachers from Egypt who are Egyptian and have the feeling for the dance.  Most importantly you will be able to watch them move and articulate the movements, and in this way you will gain some understanding of the quality that is associated with belly dance, that elusive “feeling” of belly dance that is so hard to grasp unless you have traveled extensively to the Middle East to study with master teachers. 

What I need and why I need it!

I need about $22,000 dollars to cover the cost of the FIRST ROUND of teachers.  I have already recorded many videos out of the kindness of the teachers, but of course I don’t have money to pay everyone.  This was done out of the kindness of their hearts to share their dance with the world, and their vision for how Egyptian belly dance should be presented.  The $22,000 will cover payments to the teachers as a thank you for taking the time to come to the studio and film which is usually very grueling and time consuming.  I also need to buy some more equipment to give you the highest quality video that can be produced.  In addition, I will be producing an album with the world famous Safaa Farid Negoom Orchestra to be used  for the filming and to be sold online, so we can have high quality music, free of constraints related to music rights. This will cover the cost of an editor as well,  to edit the videos which usually take about one week to edit per class,  and the editor is doing a great job of completing all the videos we have filmed thus far. 

Break it Down

Payments for teachers $12,000

Album $4,000

Editor $1,500

Equipment $2,500

Other expendables ie, website $2000

The Impact

I believe that belly dance is an amazing, magical, healing art.  I have taught cancer patients who said they beat cancer and belly dance was a big part of the reason why.  Dance heals so many people, it helps people to become healthy, it brings joy to the dancer and their audience, belly dance helps women accept their bodies and gives them greater confidence and joy in their lives.  If you want to be happy just dance!

I believe that the world needs this and belly dance needs this to survive well into the future, and to have the teachers live on in outer space always ready, willing, and able to teach you what you need to learn.  I wish that Sohair Zaki and Tahia Karioka and many other dance legends had filmed classes, and we were able to take classes online with them.  Now, all Egyptian teachers can live on indefinitely teaching by internet for as long as it stays in the ethers of the universe.  Technology is amazing and I am so grateful that we have this tool.  I hope all of these classes will be available for the next 100 years!  This is going to be a great resource to preserve the dance and I'm so excited about it. 

I hope that you can see what I envision for this project and the future of it.  I am certain that all learning will soon be online and this is an amazing opportunity to help grow this wonderful resource for our beloved dance. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute to my Indiegogo campaign, please feel free to contact me to put me in touch with anyone you think might be interested in the work I am doing. I’m also open to any kind of assistance you can give as far as input and what you would like to see online in the coming months.  In addition, another big way you can help if you can’t help financially, is to SHARE this campaign on your FB and Twitter page and all pages you are associated with. The more we share, the faster I can reach the goal and get this to you!!  Thank you for helping any way you can.  Money is not the only way to help.  If you have a belief in someone you can also help by sharing their cause. 

THANK YOU!!

I would like to say in advance, THANK YOU for your kindness, generosity and support and vision!!! I am really looking forward to this project going live and I can’t wait to present it to you and the world.

story:
Younger Child Productions will present "One, Two, Whatever you do . ." a new darkly comic play by Vanessa Shealy, in the New York International Fringe Festival in August of 2011. In order to present a production of artistic merit, fundraising is essential!   FEMALE WRITTEN, DIRECTED & PLOT CENTERED WORK is rare to find anywhere, even on a NY Stage. Our protagonist isn't in a love triangle, her struggle is between her broken dreams and her childhood fantasies. This theatrical story, universal in nature, is about who you are vs. who you are trying to be.

In ONE, TWO, WHATEVER YOU DO…former child star Angela L. Wilcox needs a job. But things spin out of control after she tells one teensy fib…and it goes viral! To save her name, Angela highjacks a local children’s theater production to beg them to tweet, or not to tweet. The resulting play becomes a darkly comic tale about a public face and the cost of keeping it well made up.
http://fab-inc.biz/blog/index.php/archives/2011/newsroom/2657

story:
What's Up?

Madame Fancypants Productions wants to make a real splash at The Toronto Fringe Festival, and independent theatre would not be possible without the generous support of the community.

  • What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise 2,000 and that goes to The Toronto Fringe Fee, rehearsal space, stilts, a few props, and a few costumes!

  • 10 dollar donation and we will give you a hug at the Fringe Tent after our show and free buttons! 
  • 25 dollar donation gets a personal invite to our opening night party
  • 100 or more gets a mention in our program and 2 free tickets to the show!

The Impact

This play is a story that needs to be told, and we believe that change will happen through the arts and this show is a seed in the growth for political change!

Other Ways You Can Help

Join us at our upcoming fundraiser, come and see the show! Tell your friends! Get out and see The Toronto Fringe TALENT! We are all amazing!
