story:
Fill in the Blank: a new evening of dance theatre by Rosie Trump | With or Without Dance

Just like a dance Mad Lib, Fill in the Blank is full of word play. Historical dance data, statistical puns, and wacky partisan declarations are the soundtrack for a tongue-in-cheek dance revelry.  Fill in the Blank explores the domestic, professional, and political pressure surrounding the contemporary woman.  Complex movement imagery waivers between thrashing and stately and the tone rides between irony and exigency in this show. 

After two years of rehearsals, Fill in the Blank is ready to premier as an evening length show at the Sugar Space Arts Warehouse in Salt Lake City, UT May 20-21, 2016.

Fill in the Blank is choreographed and directed by Rosie Trump in collaboration with professional dance performers: Eve Allen, Katie Jean Dahlaw, Ellen Duffy, and Laura Gutierrez.

What We Need 

  • We are raising $3,000 to support the travel of the dancers from Reno, NV to Salt Lake City, UT, professional rate pay for four dancers, and support for technical productions costs.
  • A $4,500 grant has already been obtained to assist with the cost of costume materials and construction, 1/4 of travel costs, partial production costs, and marketing materials.
  • In-kind donations of rehearsal and theatre rental space have already been awarded by Sugar Space Arts Warehouse to support this show.

What You Get

  • For your contributions, we have some awesome perks, including acknowledgement in the performance program, Rosie Trump | With or Without Dance swag, and more!
  • Even if we don't reach the entire goal, all funds raised will be used to produce and perform this new work of art.

More About the Artists

Rosie Trump (choreographer/director) is a dance choreographer, filmmaker, performer, educator, and the artistic director of Rosie Trump | With or Without Dance.   Trump's work is nostalgic in style, feminist, and deliberately understated.  She plays with the tension between the ordinary and the absurd in search of movement that is mutually comedic and political.

Trump’s choreography and films have been both shown nationally and internationally.  Recently, her work was presented by the Comedy in Dance Festival (NYC), the MixMatch Dance Festival (LA), the Prague Fringe Festival, Dance New Amsterdam's Frameworks (NYC), Motion Captured Film Festival (Houston), the Toothache Duets (London), and Your Move Dance Festival (NJ). 

Trump holds a MFA in Experimental Dance Choreography from UC Riverside and a BA in dance from Slippery Rock University.  Recent awards include: a Jackpot grant from the Nevada Arts Council, a Grants to Artist award from the Sierra Arts Foundation, and a Special Initiatives Grant from the Houston Arts Alliance.  She is an Assistant Professor of Dance at the University of Nevada, Reno.  Trump is the founder and curator of the annual Third Coast Dance Film Festival.

Eve Allen (dancer) is a Dance Lecturer at the University of Nevada, Reno and received her MFA in Ballet from the University of Utah. Eve also performs with A.V.A. Ballet Theatre and Belle Contemporary Dance Co. She is the founder of the Downtown Dance Collective, which presents new dance experiences in Reno, NV.  Eve is a registered teaching artist for the Sierra Arts Foundations and with the Nevada Arts Council's Artist Roster.

Katie Jean Dahlaw (dancer) is the dance maker/founder of the Great Basin Movement Project. KJ moved to Reno in June of 2013 to embark on an urban homesteading project, as well as a new job as adjunct faculty of dance at UNR. She lived in Chicago from 2003-2013 (with a short stint in Bloomington, IL, where she started the Prairieland Movement Project). While in Chicago KJ had the opportunity to dance with Matter of Reaction Movement Project, Mordine and Co. Dance Theatre, choreographer Samantha Allen, Renegade Dance Architects, Elements Contemporary ballet, and apprenticed with the Chicago Ballet. KJ is curious about being human; what it means to be a people connected to a particular place; the stories we tell ourselves; and how the human community can fully integrate into the more-than-human Earth community. Currently, KJ dances with Kristin Heavey of Element Dance Theater and Rosie Trump | With or Without Dance.

Ellen Duffy (dancer)  is a graduate of the Las Vegas Academy of Performing and Visual Arts high school.  She is perusing a BA in Journalism with a minor in Dance from the University of Nevada, Reno. Her choreography has been presented in the Mixtape Series at the Holland Project and by Downtown Dance Collective in Reno, NV.  Ellen love to travel and has visited Thailand, Tanzania, Laos, Myanmar, and Ecuador.  She is a nationally ranked synchronized swimmer and has performed as a professional mermaid.

Laura Gutierrez (dancer), a Houston-based dance artist, received a BFA in Contemporary Dance from the University of North Carolina School of the Arts in 2009, where she was awarded a William R. Kenan, Jr. Performing Arts Fellowship at the Lincoln Center Institute.   Since then Gutierrez has performed in museums such as The Menil Collection, Contemporary Arts Museum–Houston, the Fabric Workshop Museum in Philadelphia, and the SCAD Museum of Art, while her own choreography has been seen at Lincoln Center Institutes, Triskelion Arts, and Nicole Longnecker Gallery.  She has been performing in works by Jonah Boaker since 2012, and in 2014 was named one of Dance Magazine’s “25 to Watch.” 


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • You can share this campaign with your network.  Email, social media, and word of mouth shout outs are always appreciated!

Thank you for supporting the performing arts in your community and beyond!

story:
About the Company

 

"Innovative musical theatre for students, by students."
Musical Theatre Repertory at the University of Southern California was established in 2005 and is dedicated to enriching students’ lives through the production of quality musical theatre. Our goal is to provide students with the opportunity to participate in musical theatre pieces supplementary to those produced by USC. Thank you for supporting the arts and we can't wait to see you at our upcoming shows!

Sondheim's Into the Woods

"INTO THE WOODS" Music and Lyrics by STEPHEN SONDHEIM Book by JAMES LAPINE Originally Directed on Broadway by James Lapine Orchestrations by Jonathan Tunick

Licensed by Musical Theatre International

January 22 - January 25  in the Massman Theatre on the USC Campus. 

This Show:

James Lapine and Stephen Sondheim take everyone's favorite storybook characters and brings them together for a timeless yet relevant piece and rare modern classic.  The story follows a Baker and his wife who wish to have a child, Cinderella who wishes to attend the King's Festival, and Jack who wishes his cow would give milk. When the Baker and his wife learn that they cannot have a child because of a Witch's curse, the two set off on a journey to break the curse. Everyone's wish is granted, but the consequences of their actions return to haunt them later with disastrous results.

About the composer: Stephen Sondheim 


Cast:

    • Molly Chiffer- Cinderella’s Mother/ Red’s Grandmother 
    • Cole Cuomo- Baker 
    • Bella Hicks- Witch
    • Emily Hunter- Jack’s mother
    • Selene Klasner- Florinda
    • Brooke Lewis- Lucinda 
    • Rebecca Mellinger- Little Red 
    • Massimo Napoli- Narrator
    • Francesca O-Hern- Rapunzel 
    • Carlye Porrazzo- Cinderella 
    • Kalev Patrick- Jack
    • Maxine Phoenix- Baker’s Wife 
    • Sanford Reed- Cinderella’s Prince 
    • Carter Shults- Repunzel’s  Prince 
    • Maurice Welch- Steward 
    • Sarah Withers- Cinderella’s Stepmom 
    • Chris Wodniak- Mysterious Man 

Creative Team:

    • Allison Aoun- Director 
    • Taubert Nadalini- Assistant Director 
    • Anthony Lucca- Musical Director
    • Clint Blakely- Vocal Coach/ AMD 
    • Jessica Major- Stage Manager 
    • Sophie Nagar- ASM
    • Victoria Pearlman- Producer 
    • Jackson Strike- Producer
    • Justus Bradshaw- Lighting Designer
    • Liam Sterbinsky- Set Designer
    • Marly Hall- Costume Designer
    • Stephen Jensen- Sound Designer 
    • Coby Crosby- Technical Director
    • Kat Brannan-Williams- Props Master 
    • Savannah Harrow- Props Assistant
    • Meredith O’Gwynn- Makeup Designer 
    • Arielle Fishman- Producer 
    • Zach Blumner- Assistant Set Designer 
    • Christina Lelon- Assistant Costume Designer
    • Maddie Flegentreff- Assistant Lighting Designer 

What We Need 

Into the Woods, produced by Musical Theatre Repertory, is an entirely student run production, meaning every single person who contributes to our project is a USC student (Designers, Actors, Producers, Directors, etc). We all devote an enormous amount of time and effort to make this production as incredible as it can be, but we can't do everything. There are ways that you can aid in our storytelling, and that is with funding.  To mount a production, we pay for the rights, the scripts, the venue, as well as the design elements.  Aspects of a production like scenic, costumes, lighting, sound, and props are some of the details that can make a show memorable for an audience member. With your help, these possibilities will help create a beautiful story that will resonate and move our patrons for the rest of their lives.

Other Ways You Can Help

We strive to raise well beyond our goal of $1,750 so please grant us your support so we can exceed our goal! 


Any sort of contribution is greatly appreciated; no form of encouragement is too small!  Even if you are not able to financially support our production, we invite you to join us in this fairy tale production January 22nd -- 25th, 2015 in the Massman Theatre. We look forward to seeing you! 

Other ways you can help support this production is by spreading the word. Please share this page and find us on Facebook. Like our page! 

MTR is always interested in getting other students involved on their productions and with their artistic board. If you have any interest in joining one of our teams, working on one of our shows, or learning more about MTR, send us an email at uscmtr@gmail.com.

Also check out our website at uscmtr.com

Thank you for supporting Musical Theatre Repertory!

We are also very thankful for the support of the USC Undergraduate Student Government and the Theatre Students Association of USC.

Sarah Withers- Cinderella’s Stepmom 


Chris Wodniak- Mysterious Man 

Creative Team:

Allison Aoun- Director 
Taubert Nadalini- Assistant Director 
Anthony Lucca- Musical Director
Clint Blakely- Vocal Coach/ AMD 
Jessica Major- Stage Manager

What We Need Into the Woods, produced by Musical Theatre Repertory, is an entirely student run production, meaning every single person who contributes to our project is a USC student (Designers, Actors, Producers, Directors, etc). We all devote an enormous amount of time and effort to make this production as incredible as it can be, but we can't do everything. There are ways that you can aid in our storytelling, and that is with funding.  To mount a production, we pay for the rights, the scripts, the venue, as well as the design elements.  Aspects of a production like scenic, costumes, lighting, sound, and props are some of the details that can make a show memorable for an audience member. With your help, these possibilities will help create a beautiful story that will resonate and move our patrons for the rest of their lives.Other Ways You Can HelpWe strive to raise well beyond our goal of $1,750 so please grant us your support so we can exceed our goal! Any sort of contribution is greatly appreciated; no form of encouragement is too small!  Even if you are not able to financially support our production, we invite you to join us in this fairy tale production January 22nd -- 25th, 2015 in the Massman Theatre. We look forward to seeing you! Other ways you can help support this production is by spreading the word. Please share this page and find us on Facebook. Like our page! MTR is always interested in getting other students involved on their productions and with their artistic board. If you have any interest in joining one of our teams, working on one of our shows, or learning more about MTR, send us an email at uscmtr@gmail.com.Also check out our website at uscmtr.comThank you for supporting Musical Theatre Repertory!We are also very thankful for the support of the USC Undergraduate Student Government and the Theatre Students Association of USC.

story:
Not Man Apart is raising $20,000 for their upcoming 2016 show,                                           The SuperHero and his Charming Wife.

NMA’s signature style is true physical theatre; a marriage of brilliant, classical literature and explosive, compelling movement.

Named one of the top innovative physical theatre companies in the world by Back Stage West, our form is athletic, dynamic, surreal and superreal.

WHAT WE NEED: We are a not-for-profit (501c3) arts organization; our productions are entirely supported by ticket sales and donations. From rehearsal spaces and marketing, to set pieces, costumes, and our amazing performance space, your tax-deductible contributions will go directly to the production of this unique show.

WHAT YOU GET: In addition to your choice of PERKS listed to the right, you get an original play, written and directed by Aaron Hendry, choreographed by Michelle Broussard, produced by Laura Covelli, and starring Jones Welsh, as The Superhero.

Rooted in NMA's passion for the Classics, The SuperHero and his Charming Wife is modern mythology. A mix of the Jungian archetype with the Eastern spiritual warrior, it is an epic tale for a pop-culture world.

                       The SuperHero and his Charming Wife

The SuperHero: The champion of constancy and order, the vanquisher of           chaos and doubt. Change is not easy for him. In fact, it’s his worst enemy.

....Enter his Charming Wife. In search of herself, she HAS to change. 

Their marriage is thrust into the unknown, and they are forced to weigh              what they fear against what they believe…

We are thrilled to co-present this new work with Leo Garcia and the Highways Performance Space, a champion of innovative performance in Los Angeles for over 20 years.  

THE ONGOING IMPACT OF NMA IN THE COMMUNITY: We believe the greatest depth of our humanity is discovered in relationship with others. Not man apart, but man together.

NMA strives to create life-affirming, consciousness expanding art that is relatable, relevant and transformative for our audiences and community. During past productions we have worked in partnership with organizations such as New Directions for Veterans, The Soldiers Project, Art and Action; and are currently spearheading the new Movement Program at Pepperdine University. Exceeding our 20K goal would allow us to continue to extend our work to the community! 

Perhaps not since the emerging Theatre Movement Bazaar has a physical theatre troupe demonstrated such purposeful integrity. Indeed it would be madness to miss it. – LA Times (Ajax in Iraq)

Pericles Redux – 2009
Titus Redux – 2010
Hercules Furens – 2011
Falling – 2012
Lysistrata – 2013
Ajax in Iraq – 2014
NMA presents East West – 2015

                         AND COMING IN 2016…

                           The SuperHero and his Charming Wife

Please help us to bring our next innovative theatrical event to the LA stage!

http://notmanapart.com/

http://highwaysperformance.org/highways/

story:
Maligrad Contemporary Dance Company is a new performance company based out of the Bay Area. The company was founded in the EU and has since made it's full time home San Francisco under the direction of Molly Fletcher Lynch. After the development and creation of the company in Croatia, Maligrad has spent the past year working with it's company members to develop and perform work that is founded in research, curiosity and serious grit. 

SOLID DISH is one such piece that was created from scratch using the artistic voices of the San Francisco company to explore what it means to be solid. Can something truly be unbreakable and if so how does that relate to change? The work is a look at what we have, if anything, that is untouchable, resistant to breakage,  solid.  How do we manifest a sense of solid ground underneath us while remaining supple, vulnerable and fluid within our environment? These are questions that are explored through curious collaboration with the dancers and their experience together, onstage, and as people in the world.  The piece is a reflection of honest inquiry and research, and lends itself to the questioning ear, rather than the mouth that answers.

After it's debut at the SAFEhouse in February, the piece has since been selected for SPF9 (summer performance festival) in July. This prestigious festival selects local dance companies to present their work on the ODC mainstage for a technically supported show, with a highly discounted fee to rent the theater. SOLID DISH will be performing JULY 9th at 5pm and JULY 10th at 9pm and we are absoluetley honored and thrilled.

In order to participate and show our work at ODC we need a bit of a push financially to cover basic fees such as the following:

Theater rental: $750

Artist fees: $500

Costumes/ props: $200

Marketing costs: $200

story:
THE TRIP is thrilled to announce a tour of Orpheus & Eurydice to New York this summer for five performances, July 16-20, at Theaterlab, a respected venue for experimental theater in the heart of Manhattan (West 36th Street). 

NOMINATED in the category of Best New Play by the San Diego Theater Critics Circle, Orpheus & Eurydice adapts the famous myth in two parts through a blend of online exchanges, live performance, and film. The lovers’ long-distance relationship unfolds through a series of video exchanges (originally released episodically over several weeks, now fully available HERE). They fall more and more in love until they can’t bear the distance distance any longer, and they agree to meet—actually, they agree to get married! The rest of their story is then staged as the live performance that we hope to bring to New York. 

WHILE THE TRIP is wholeheartedly a San Diego theater company (and we will announce an exciting new production in San Diego very soon!), we nevertheless recognize the importance of sharing what we do elsewhere, to ensure that THE TRIP keeps growing. From the very beginning our work has been for YOU, and the bigger that YOU becomes, the more we can do. We can send photos and Vimeo links till we’re orange in the face, but there is no substitute for introducing ourselves and our work in the flesh. 

PRESENTING a show in New York is a costly affair involving space rental, travel from California, housing, gear rental, and of course, reasonable compensation for the artists who work so hard for us. We have been as creative as possible, negotiating all the favors we can, including a generous rental fee from our supportive presenters, Theaterlab. But we remain $3000 shy of what is needed to make this tour happen. We are coming to you now in the hope that you can help us get there, and from the bottom of our hearts, we are grateful for anything you can give.

Tom & Josh

***

Press for Orpheus & Eurydice

“THE TRIP, a fledgling company…has made its mark [in San Diego] with immersive, boundary-testing work. And Orpheus & Eurydice, its latest piece, brims with ideas and energy…When it comes to traditional notions of storytelling, [THE TRIP shows] few signs of looking back.” - James Hebert, San Diego Union-Tribune

“And THE TRIP does like to provoke. Their productions are unique, often antic, with elements of testosterone-fueled adolescence…[They] are imaginative and risk-taking, and they’re hellbent on expanding the boundaries of theater…” - Pat Launer, The Times of San Diego

story: We have stumbled upon an opportunity to purchase an incredible collection of costumes and props for our family-friendly theatre company Goodger-Pink Productions. This is an amazing opportunity for us because we pride ourselves on keeping our tickets financially accessible for everyone and therefore we are always trying to be very creative with a very small costume and prop budget. But this could change everything for us! This is a 20 year collection of hundreds and hundreds of costumes and props, of all shapes and styles. This is where you come in! We can put up about half of the money but we need your help to make up the other half. And we promise to make it worth your while! Free costume rentals in exchange for your donation! Whether you are another theatre company that could benefit from access to hundreds of beautiful costumes, someone who loves Halloween just a little too much, or someone who simply likes dressing up in a costume and dancing around the living room! We don't judge, we just need your money in exchange for good karma and the opportunity to play dress up!

story:
Short Summary

OYSTER is a group of theatre artists from Canada who have been working together on and off since the fall of 2014. Our inaugural show premiered while we were students at Concordia University, and since then we have had one remount, and are now invited to The ARENA… of the Young Arts Festival in Erlangen, Germany.


The ARENA...of the Young Arts Festival has been running for over 25 years  and successful launching place for experimental  artists from around the world. It is a juried festival, and the learning for us as a group of emerging artists will be huge.

What We Need & What You Get

We need money to help fund travel, accommodation and living expenses in Germany. The festival was not able to provide funds for the entire team to travel, and so all contributions will help the whole team participate in this unique international experience and see the fruits of their (really fun and fabulous) labor performed on a German stage! This amount will also be used to pay for the design budget: to ensure the artistic and aesthetic quality of our show and  bring it to a high level of professionalism! Our design needs include: stylish wigs,make-up, colorful and outrageous costume pieces for two performers, lush and expressive fabrics for the set, paint and building materials...

We are so grateful to anyone willing to contribute and we want to express our thanks. For $5: you get an Instagram shoutout, for $10 you get cheap art, for $20 you get a personalized poem, for $50 you get a special mention in the show, for $100 you get a postcard from Germany... Wow! Wow! Wow! So don't miss out!

The Impact

    Oyster believes in ~ FRIVOLITY RESISTING BULLSHIT! ~  Our work looks to fun things, silly aesthetics, dances of humour and sincerity, and beautiful frivolity as a tool to resist cultural norms. Playing on the farce of Missie as the Artist and Arty as her Art, OYSTER looks to ~ GLAMOUR AS ARMOUR ~ to critique the boring machismo of the art world and rethink gendered representation in the arts. We look to the idea that art is for staving off existential self-destruction and that everyday thoughtful aesthetics matter in finding the truth, strength, and humour in our daily performances of our online and offline selves.

    Most members of this team are graduates of a B.F.A. Theatre program, and have all had experience working on many kinds of theatre.  We have performed this show twice already and audiences have responded very well to it to its playful, hilarious, poetic and critical content. Furthermore, Missie has a large fan base and a strong presence on the social media. We are definitely ready and excited to bring this show to an international platform! 

Risks & Challenges

Some obstacles we have and will continue to face are material needs and costs. Nonetheless, we are a creative and resourceful team of artists and we are dedicated to making quality art  with all the materials we can get an recycle. Of course, your contribution  would
Another one of our challenges is to maintain our collectivity. We are aiming as much as possible to attend this trip together, and that requires funding. We have tried different sources, and are turning to the Web as another opportunity. 

Other Ways You Can Help

No matter what, we really appreciate your likes on Instagram and Facebook, so please follow @ mmissie__me!! Now that you know a bit more about us, are you a bit bummed you can’t make it out to Germany? Well don't be! Come see our performance this Wednesday June 1st and enjoy fancy drinks, snacks and great theatre with us instead! We'll see you there!
https://www.facebook.com/events/565663146949313/

story:
Hot off the success of the 2013 World Premiere of Julian Sheppard's "Owned", Knife Edge Productions is proud to present Stephen Belber's "Fault Lines".  "Fault Lines" will run at the beautiful 99 seat TBG Theatre in midtown Manhattan from 9/4/14 - 9/20/14.  

"A cautionary comedy about the fragility of friendship." -- The New York Daily News

"Crackles with terrific dialogue..." -- The New York Post

"Brittle, blunt and also wonderfully cryptic...Belber's riveting play defies expectations at every turn." -- CurtainUp

" ...a play that will have spectators literally gasping as surprise succeeds surprise." -- TheatreMania.com

"FAULT LINES, a sly and extremely satisfying new work...is not only cleverly constructed, it's also very funny.  Punctuated with laughs that come out of character, rather than out of joke lines, this is a show that deserves to run and run..." -- Talkin' Broadway

THE PLAY

"When Jim and Bill get together to celebrate Bill's thirty-ninth birthday, they meet Joe, who's slightly older and odder, and their boys' night out quickly turns sour.  Whole Foods, mini-hot dogs and Edie Brickell abound as together they attempt to delineate loyalty, conviction and betrayal."

"Fault Lines" is about the increasing fragility of friendship as time goes by.  At its core it's about two friends who seek to remain best friends even as they veer in separate directions.  It asks some very important questions: 

At what price is it worth holding onto a relationship that may no longer know its heart?  Should we make the extra effort, bend over backwards or even loosen our moral structures just to keep alive a friendship whose time has maybe come?  Isn't that what friendship is? --- making the extra effort to understand, being there for someone --- most vitally when they're lost?  

Through humor, deceit, the threat of betrayal and in the context of jealousy and love, the characters in this play strive, stumble and stupefy each other as they try to navigate the messy waters of impending middle age.

THE TEAM

Stephen Belber (Playwright): Stephen's plays have been produced on Broadway and over 25 countries. They include "Fault Lines", "Tape", "Match", "The Power of Duff", "Don't Go Gentle", "Dusk Rings a Bell", "McReele", "A Small, Melodramatic Story" and "Geometry of Fire".  He was an Associate Writer on "The Laramie Project" and co-writer on "The Laramie Project: Ten Years Later".  His television credits include "Rescue Me" and "Law and Order: SVU".  His movie credits include "Tape", starring Ethan Hawke, Uma Thurman and Robert Sean Leonard, "The Laramie Project" (Associate Writer), "Management" (Writer/Director), starring Jennifer Aniston and "Match" (Writer/Director) starring Patrick Stewart, which will be released in January.

Shira-Lee Shalit (Director): Shira-Lee is an award-winning director, selected by Steven Spielberg as a finalist for the TV show "On the Lot." Named by "Shoot" Magazine as a director to watch, Shira-Lee directs film and theatre and is on faculty at both NYU and Columbia University. She works with the LAByrinth Theatre Company where she teaches their master class workshops and is an Associate Director with the Barefoot Theatre Company. Shira-Lee has a BFA in Acting from NYU and received her MFA in Directing at Columbia University's Graduate Film Division.

Neil Holland (Actor/Lead Producer): Neil's past self-produced productions include Stephen Belber's "Tape" at the June Havoc Theatre, the World Premiere of "Owned"by Drama Desk nominated playwright Julian Sheppard at the TBG Theatre and Adam Rapp's "Red Light Winter" at Theatre 54.  He also produced the web series "Guys in a Hot Tub Talking".  Some of his film and television credits include "White Collar", "All My Children", "One Life to Live" and "As the World Turns",  

Chaz Reuben (Actor/Associate Producer): Chaz's past productions include "Real Black Men..." (Audelco Award) at the New Federal Theatre, "365 Days/365 Plays" at the Public Theatre and "Romeo and Juliet" with the Classical Theatre of Harlem.

Don DiPaolo (Producer): Don is a producer with Knife Edge Productions and has previously produced Stephen Belber's "Tape" at the June Havoc Theatre and the World Premiere of "Owned"by Drama Desk nominated playwright Julian Sheppard at the TBG Theatre.

Michael Puzzo (Actor): Michael is an actor, playwright and producer.  He has been a member of LAByrinth Theater Company since 1997. His acting credits include four original works by John Patrick Shanley (including playing Father Sherman in his film adaption of "Doubt") as well as new plays by Brett C. Leonard, Stephen Adly Guirgis, Eric Bogosian and many others. His plays have been published by Dramatist Play Service, Smith & Kraus, New York Theater Experience and have been  produced all over the world. 

Danelle Eliav (Actress): Danelle is actress, filmmaker and producer. Select Acting Credits: "Carnival Kids" (Lesser America, NY Times Critic’s Pick), "Suite Horovitz" and "Mid-East Pieces" (Barefoot Theatre), "Cynthia and the Dreadful Kite" (LAByrinth Workshop),"Romeo and Juliet" & "A Midsummer Night’s Dream" (Allentown Shakespeare). Her short film "The Girl and the Spanish Boy "won awards at festivals worldwide and is now playing on Shorts TV.  She produced and acted in indie feature "Emoticon ;)" (Winner Best Cast Gen Art FF) which just finished its theatrical release in NY and LA. 

Nick Francone (Scenic/Lighting Designer):  Nick is the Resident Scenic and Lighting Designer / Producing Director with Vampire Cowboys Theatre Company. Other New York scenic and lighting design credits include "Thieves" at the Public Theater, "Fast Company", "Isaac’s Eye", "Marathon 2013" and "Photograph 51" at Ensemble Studio Theatre and World Science Festival, "Alice Grace Anon", "Goldor $ Mythica" and "The Germ Project" with New Georges and "Radiance" with Labyrinth Theater Company. Recent Assisting credits include Wicked- Broadway, London, Chicago, Japan, Germany, Los Angeles, Australia, Holland, Mexico, Korea, UK Tour, and two North American National Tours.

Nancy Leary (Costume Designer): Nancy's theatrical career spans two decades. Her costumes have appeared on the stages of The Pittsburgh Symphony, Virginia Opera, Boston Lyric Opera, Weston Playhouse, Opera Boston, Orlando Shakespeare Festival, Chautauqua Opera, Shakespeare Theatre New Jersey, Mobile Opera, Actor’s Shakespeare Project, Juilliard Opera, The Modern and on the Boston Common for Commonwealth Shakespeare Company. Nancy has completed several pieces for Knife Edge Productions, notably Stephen Belber’s "Tape" and Julian Sheppard’s "Owned". 

Daniel Spitaliere (Sound Designer): Daniel is a freelance sound designer and engineer who has been working in sound professionally since 2007. Design credits include productions with Knife Edge Productions, Ballybeg Productions, Ensemble Studio Theatre, ManTown Productions, The Possibility Project, and Summer Repertory Theatre (Santa Rosa, CA). Engineering credits include productions with Playwrights Horizons, HERE Arts Center, and Barrow Street Theatre.

Kate Jordan Rivera (Production Stage Manager): Kate has a BA in theatre from Seattle Pacific University. Some Regional PA Credits include: Rapture, Blister Burn (ACT Theatre), Elf (5th Avenue Theatre), and Pippi Longstocking (Seattle Children’s Theatre). She has also spent many years as an IATSE Stagehand at Seattle Children’s Theatre. 

Chimmy Anne Gunn (Technical Director): Chimmy grew up in Texas and ran away with the circus (twice) before landing in New York.  She makes a living turning ideas into tangible objects and wrangling electrons for theatre, television, dance, and performance art.

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

We have already raised $18,000 and find ourselves more than halfway to our goal of $35,000!  But we still have work to do -- we need to raise another $17,000 to cover the remaining expenses which include:

  • Theatre Rental: $9,820
  • Rehearsal Space: $3,000 
  • Scenery and Props (Yes, this really includes a pool table):  $4,000 +

With rehearsals beginning on 7/28 and performances beginning on 9/4, we need the support of amazing theatre-lovers like YOU to make this happen!

To say THANK YOU for your support, your donations are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law and we are offering wide array of exciting perks:

  • Tickets to the show
  • Caputo & Co. bracelets
  • Personal Training Sessions
  • Autographed Posters
  • Invitations to a working rehearsal
  • Invitations to the opening night reception

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

Every production has risks and challenges.  Heck, that's one of the biggest reasons why we do it! There's a reason we call ourselves Knife Edge Productions. That being said, we are setting ourselves up for success because if there is one thing that is certain, it's that the production will only be as GREAT as the people who are involved in it.  To that end, every single person that is involved in this production is GREAT at what they do.  

Also, did we mention that "Fault Lines" will be the FOURTH production from Knife Edge Productions?  We have a proven track record. 

To quote Stephen Belber:  

"There are two types of actors: There are those that go to LA and try and luck into something big, and then there are those who stay in NY and work on their craft and hustle.  And these guys (Neil Holland and Don DiPaolo) are above and beyond that.  I mean, they are the epitome of wanting to put their money where there mouth is, and more, their hard work where their mouth is."

The bottom line is this:  We are dedicated to creating and producing high quality works that we are extremely passionate about that will push the boundaries as we know it. If you support us, we promise we won't let you down.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Please make some noise about this production and our fundraising campaign. Take advantage of the sharing tools found right here on our Indie Go Go page (at the top of the page) to help us spread the word:

  • Facebook
  • Twitter
  • Google+ 
  • Reach out to friends, family members, colleagues and acquaintances. All you have to do is click the "Email" button. 

All of these steps will go a long way in helping us meet our goal.  And the more active our page is, the more our "gogofactor" increases, giving us a greater chance of being featured on the Indie Go Go home page.  

With your support and enthusiasm we can give "Fault Lines" the stellar production we envision for it. 

Thank YOU!

-- Knife Edge Productions
story_txt:
Hot off the success of the 2013 World Premiere of Julian Sheppard's "Owned", Knife Edge Productions is proud to present Stephen Belber's "Fault Lines".  "Fault Lines" will run at the beautiful 99 seat TBG Theatre in midtown Manhattan from 9/4/14 - 9/20/14.  
"A cautionary comedy about the fragility of friendship." -- The New York Daily News"Crackles
with terrific dialogue..." -- The New York Post
"Brittle,
blunt and also wonderfully cryptic...Belber's riveting play defies expectations
at every turn." -- CurtainUp
" ...a
play that will have spectators literally gasping as surprise succeeds
surprise." -- TheatreMania.com
"FAULT
LINES, a sly and extremely satisfying new work...is not only cleverly
constructed, it's also very funny. 
Punctuated with laughs that come out of character, rather than out of
joke lines, this is a show that deserves to run and run..." -- Talkin'
BroadwayTHE PLAY
"When Jim and Bill get together to celebrate Bill's thirty-ninth birthday, they meet Joe, who's slightly older and odder, and their boys' night out quickly turns sour.  Whole Foods, mini-hot dogs and Edie Brickell abound as together they attempt to delineate loyalty, conviction and betrayal.""Fault Lines" is about the increasing fragility of friendship as time goes by.  At its core it's about two friends who seek to remain best friends even as they veer in separate directions.  It asks some very important questions: At what price is it worth holding onto a relationship that may no longer know its heart?  Should we make the extra effort, bend over backwards or even loosen our moral structures just to keep alive a friendship whose time has maybe come?  Isn't that what friendship is? --- making the extra effort to understand, being there for someone --- most vitally when they're lost?  Through humor, deceit, the threat of betrayal and in the context of jealousy and love, the characters in this play strive, stumble and stupefy each other as they try to navigate the messy waters of impending middle age.THE TEAMStephen Belber (Playwright): Stephen's plays have been produced on Broadway and over 25
countries. They include "Fault Lines", "Tape", "Match", "The Power of Duff", "Don't Go Gentle", "Dusk Rings a Bell", "McReele", "A Small, Melodramatic Story" and "Geometry of Fire".  He was an Associate Writer on "The Laramie Project" and co-writer on "The Laramie Project: Ten Years Later".  His television credits include "Rescue Me" and "Law and Order: SVU".  His movie credits include "Tape", starring Ethan Hawke, Uma Thurman and Robert Sean Leonard, "The Laramie Project" (Associate Writer), "Management" (Writer/Director), starring Jennifer Aniston and "Match" (Writer/Director) starring Patrick Stewart, which will be released in January.Shira-Lee Shalit (Director): Shira-Lee is an award-winning director, selected by Steven Spielberg as a finalist for the TV show "On the Lot." Named by "Shoot" Magazine as a director to watch, Shira-Lee directs film and theatre and is on faculty at both NYU and Columbia University. She works with the LAByrinth Theatre Company where she teaches their master class workshops and is an Associate Director with the Barefoot Theatre Company. Shira-Lee has a BFA in Acting from NYU and received her MFA in Directing at Columbia University's Graduate Film Division.Neil Holland (Actor/Lead Producer): Neil's past self-produced productions include Stephen Belber's "Tape" at the June Havoc Theatre, the World Premiere of "Owned"by Drama Desk nominated playwright Julian Sheppard at the TBG
Theatre and Adam Rapp's "Red Light Winter" at Theatre 54.  He also produced the web series "Guys in a Hot Tub Talking".  Some of his film and television credits include "White
Collar", "All My Children", "One Life to Live" and "As the World Turns",  Chaz Reuben (Actor/Associate Producer): Chaz's past productions include "Real Black Men..." (Audelco Award) at the New Federal Theatre, "365 Days/365 Plays" at the Public Theatre and "Romeo and Juliet" with the Classical Theatre of Harlem.Don DiPaolo (Producer): Don is a producer with Knife Edge Productions and has previously produced Stephen Belber's "Tape" at the June Havoc Theatre and the World Premiere of "Owned"by Drama Desk nominated playwright Julian Sheppard at the TBG Theatre.Michael Puzzo (Actor): Michael is an actor, playwright and producer.  He has been a member of
LAByrinth Theater Company since 1997. His acting credits include four original
works by John Patrick Shanley (including playing Father Sherman in his film adaption of "Doubt") as well as new plays by Brett C. Leonard, Stephen Adly Guirgis, Eric
Bogosian and many others. His plays have been published by Dramatist Play
Service, Smith & Kraus, New York Theater Experience and have been  produced all
over the world. Danelle Eliav (Actress): Danelle is actress, filmmaker and producer. Select Acting Credits: "Carnival Kids" (Lesser America, NY Times Critic’s Pick), "Suite Horovitz" and "Mid-East Pieces" (Barefoot Theatre), "Cynthia and the Dreadful Kite" (LAByrinth Workshop),"Romeo and Juliet" & "A Midsummer Night’s Dream" (Allentown Shakespeare). Her short film "The Girl and the Spanish Boy "won awards at festivals worldwide and is now playing on Shorts TV.  She produced and acted in indie feature "Emoticon ;)" (Winner Best Cast Gen Art FF) which just finished its theatrical release in NY and LA. Nick Francone (Scenic/Lighting Designer):  Nick is the Resident Scenic and Lighting Designer / Producing Director with Vampire Cowboys Theatre Company. Other New York scenic and lighting design credits include "Thieves" at the Public Theater, "Fast Company", "Isaac’s Eye", "Marathon 2013" and "Photograph 51" at Ensemble Studio Theatre and World Science Festival, "Alice Grace Anon", "Goldor $ Mythica" and "The Germ Project" with New Georges and "Radiance" with Labyrinth Theater Company. Recent Assisting credits include Wicked- Broadway, London, Chicago, Japan, Germany, Los Angeles, Australia, Holland, Mexico, Korea, UK Tour, and two North American National Tours.Nancy Leary (Costume Designer): Nancy's theatrical career spans two decades. many years as an IATSE Stagehand at Seattle Children’s Theatre. Chimmy Anne Gunn (Technical Director): Chimmy grew up in Texas and

story:
Professional Classical Theatre -- Fresh, Bold, and Entertaining. 

Short Summary

So here is the deal -- We at Rubber City Shakespeare Company are stepping things up for our fall season! Our concepts for the fall are Taming of the Shrew set in the 1920's style and 'Tis Pity She's a Whore in a steampunk style. We need your help to help us make these concepts a reality onstage. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need an additional $500 (or more.. we will never say no to more money!) to make these costume concepts a reality! All $500 will be going towards our costumes for this fall! 

What do you get? Our forever gratitude and some cool perks:

$10 Swatch - A shout out on Facebook and Twitter. 

$25 Quick Change - Your name in a special costume "Thank you" in our programs, plus the previous levels. 

$40  Costume Fitting - You will receive a Fall Poster signed by the cast, plus the previous levels. 

$50 Costume parade - You will receive a special costume ornament for the holiday season! This ornament will contain pieces of fabric used in our costume. Plus the previous levels! 

Challenges for RCSC

Outside of payroll, Costumes are our biggest expense. When you come to see our professional actors, we want you to be blown away by their awesome acting and their fabulous costumes. 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Spread the word about our campaign! Share on Facebook and email your friends about it.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools! It makes the whole thing a lot easier.

story:
Hello, thank you for viewing my campaign! My name is Jessa deLancey and dance is both my passion and my profession. In 2012 I created the Santa Cruz Silvestre Residency project, an opportunity to learn, create, and perform with world renowned dance teacher Rosangela Silvestre from Salvador da Bahia, Brazil. I hosts Rosangela for a week of workshops and rehearsals that culminates in a full dance production that involves local and Bay Area artists, musicians, and professional dance companies. Educational outreach is also a component of this project. I completed this project in both 2012 and 2013 as the sole producer, and now I need your help to keep it going! This project enriches our community in a multitude of ways. 

Your contribution will help us grow this project into an even more spectacular event! Funds raised will go toward renting a beautiful venue with a large stage, paying the guest artists including musicians, dance companies, and Rosangela, hiring a professional tech and stage crew, renting necessary equipment, advertising to reach a larger audience, hiring a professional videographer, and purchasing materials for costumes and props. 
 Any amount will help tremendously! A few dollars or as much as you can afford, anything will make a difference. Donating at the Bronze Level and above will get your name printed in the show program, at the Silver Level you will also receive a DVD of the performance and free participation in one of the workshops, at the Gold Level you will received a DVD and free participation in ALL of the workshops, and at the Platinum Level you will receive 2 free tickets to the performance, a DVD, and free participation in ALL of the workshops!
By contributing to this campaign, you will be supporting Cultural Arts in Santa Cruz, helping to provide this incredible opportunity to the participants and the contributing artists, and helping to inspire audience members and participants alike.  Your contribution is invaluable! Make a donation today!
If you are unable to donate, please get the word out about the campaign by sharing it via email and facebook,  and by telling your friends!  
Let's keep this project going!  Let's create Art!

story:
Laughter, heartbreak and Chinese food figure into Sarah Was Mine, where David takes us on a journey through his memories while desperately trying to come to grips with his sexuality. True love, friendship and honesty are explored by three actors over two acts that span the 70's and 80's in pre-AIDS America.


We are raising money to help us be a part of the Unfringed Festival at The Secret Theatre. This is a great opportunity to get Joe Fletchers beautiful story seen and heard .

story:
You'd get PERICLES: A Bluegrass Fairytale.

We've created a show that combines: a Shakespearean classic; great actors who play banjo, guitar, mandolin, fiddle, and bass; 20 new bluegrass/folk tunes; a metric ton of funny hats and beards; and PIRATES!

In 2013 we brought our minimalist approach to classic stories to New York with TEMPEST NYC. Now we're looking to bring our style to The City again and we've collaborated with an amazing bluegrass musician to help us do it.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Let's cut to the chase, shall we? We need $6,000 to 1: pay the amazing actor/musicians and the designers and 2: create set pieces, props, and costumes. It's an EPIC story and even though we're a minimalist company (we don't need a boat and a chorus of 20 for-cryin'-out-loud) it takes more than you might think to tell the story in a clear and simple way. Especially in New York City.

So, if this a project you'd like to support, decide what giving tier you'd like to be a part of. But whatever tier you choose, please know that this production is funded by you and is for you. Art for the people, baby. We couldn't do it without your contribution and it really means the world to us to have your support.

                         

The Impact

By helping us meet our goal you'll let us take Shakespeare back to it's foot-stompin' roots and help us win back the trust of bored English students everywhere.

You'll also be directly affecting the creative lives of stellar actor/musicians and designers, and providing high quality, affordable live entertainment options to the people in New York City.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have $1 to give then please spread the word about the campaign. The share tools are a great resource and only take a few seconds. The more you share the more people will have the opportunity to help make PERICLES: A Bluegrass Fairytale a reality.

story:
Baby Freedman

26 years-old, unwed, and pregnant in the 1950's, Toby traveled to California and gave birth to a girl known only as "Baby Freedman" to her adoptive parents, Sally and Malcolm. Toby returned to New York, married a different man, and never mentioned Baby Freedman.

Fast forward to 1971 and Baby Freedman, now 13 year-old Sharon, starts asking questions about her biological family.  These questions take Sharon on a cross-country, decades-long biological scavenger hunt. 
Crafted from a series of interviews, written artifacts and legal documents, and a collection of family photos, Yet Un-Named traces the women and fantastic circumstances that make up director Sara Rademacher's heritage. More than just a personal story of the search for roots, the project questions what "family" is, and how-- through biology and circumstance-- we all choose the tribe that becomes our family.

    Support Our Story

    Our devising team is weaving a story from the various articles and interviews that catalog the lives of Toby and Sharon, and unfortunately, although tickets to the show are free, bringing this vision and story to life is not free. Here's what your donation will do for us:

    • Purchase materials and supplies to construct the world of Yet- Un-Named
    • Clothe and light our actors
    • Pay our people! We have an amazing devising team. Sure, they're priceless, but we'd like to give them a little something for putting their heart and soul into this story! 

    Our Family

    Production Team
    Sara Rademacher - Director
    Meghan Dixon - Producer
    Stephen Davan - Set Designer
    Blake Kile - Lighting/Projection Design
    Weizhi Ke - Stage Manager
    Yet- Un-Named will be performed by: 
    Starr Kirkland - Actor/Co-creator
    Jen Michaels - Actor/Co-creator
    Samantha Posey - Actor/Co-creator
    Chelsea Whitehead  - Actor/Co-creator


    Join us!

    Where? 
    Schapiro Theatre 
    (115th St. Between Riverside Drive and Broadway)

    When?
    October 31st @ 7:30pm
    November 1st @ 2pm
    November 1st @ 7:30pm
    November 2nd @ 2pm

    Tickets available via e-mail at
    yetunnamed2014@gmail.com

    Directions: Take the 1 Train to 116th Street. Exit and walk west on 115th St. Schapiro Hall will be on your right halfway between Broadway and Riverside Drive. Go to the basement of Schapiro Hall.

    A Special Thank You

    To those who allowed us to bring this story to life through their interviews and letters: Sharon, Loren, Andy, Peter, Helen, Miriam, Shele, Ricki, Judy and Toby.
    Yet Un-Named is dedicated to Toby, Sally, and Sharon, the mothers who made this story possible.

Where? Schapiro Theatre (115th St. Between Riverside Drive and Broadway)When?October 31st @ 7:30pmNovember 1st @ 2pmNovember 1st @ 7:30pmNovember 2nd @ 2pmTickets available via e-mail atyetunnamed2014@gmail.comDirections: Take the 1 Train to 116th Street. Exit and walk west on 115th St. Schapiro Hall will be on your right halfway between Broadway and Riverside Drive. Go to the basement of Schapiro Hall.

A Special Thank You


To those who allowed us to bring this story to life through their interviews and letters: Sharon, Loren, Andy, Peter, Helen, Miriam, Shele, Ricki, Judy and Toby.
Yet Un-Named is dedicated to Toby, Sally, and Sharon, the mothers who made this story possible.

story:
Contribute today to the first BlakTina Dance Festival in Tucson - supporting and forging new boundaries in the dance festival scene!

BlakTina - Tucson, is a movement festival celebrating Black and Latina (o) choreographers, and was the brain child of Licia Perea.  Our growing success, over the past two seasons in Los Angeles, is creating a buzz and excitement about this inspiring festival!  Join our art force today and support dance and movement artists of color in our community!  


Licia Perea, Producing Director of BlakTina - LA, and Eva Tessler, both of the Latina Dance Theater Project,  are working to bring this new boundary-defying festival, born from the diverse cultural and artistic landscape of Los Angeles, to the Old Pueblo.  


Inspiring Artists of Color of all ages!

This inspiring festival gives local and regional dance/movement, performance, and theater artists, (of diverse backgrounds, experience and disciplines) an opportunity to present and create new work to share with our diverse Tucson audiences!  In this artistic landscape which tends to reflect only a small portion of our changing demographics, BlakTina provides not only a platform for artists of color, but serves as inspiration for up and coming artists as they identify and visualize themselves on stage.  Part of the mission of The Latina Dance Theater Project, is to provide opportunities for youth to participate in the arts.  Along with our evening shows, BlakTina will present interactive performances for student groups from local high schools.  In the future, we hope to add interactive workshops as we look to share this work with other community groups, schools, and organizations.  

You can bring BlakTina to Tucson

Our goal during this Indiegogo campaign is to raise $3000 to help support BlakTina - Tucson. The funds raised will go towards paying our lighting designer, tech crew, PR for this seasons production, travel, space, artist sty-pen, and education outreach expenses.    

Every dollar amount counts:  Both small and large contributions will take us closer to our goal!  And, all contributions are tax deductible and greatly appreciated!


Other Ways You Can Help!

Artists need to Eat and Sleep:  You can help BlakTina by providing meals for our local and guest artists through gift cards for local eateries and accommodations, and/or donating a meal from your establishment.

Artists need help:  Donate your time and body to the arts by ushering for BlakTina; volunteering to guide traffic; organizing your own "Friends don't let Friends go to the Arts alone" group; or offering your home to a nosh and booze, "lets raise funds for the arts" get-together with your buddies and Latina Dance Theater Project representatives!

Artists need your voice:  Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools and spread the word about our BlakTina - Tucson campaign, friend us on facebook, visit our website, and indulge your text, tumble, and tweet tendencies!  

Artists need YOU:  Buy your tickets now and create your own public Buzz! 

Thank you for your much needed support,                                                                       Latina Dance Theater Project

Look for our website: www.blaktinafestival.com (Arizona)

story:
Who We Are: Multicultural Alliance Theatre

Multicultural Alliance Theatre (MAT) is a student initiated and student-run club, operating out of the Performing Arts Department at Savannah College of Art & Design (SCAD) in Savannah, Ga.

Our mission is to produce plays and musicals that feature minorities in leading roles, while also allowing non-minorities to participate. The productions are artistically excellent, thought provoking, relevant, and illuminate the human condition through the sharing of stories that either depict specific cultural groups and examine issues of identity and relationship to the majority culture, or stories that can be interpreted in a multicultural context.


(MAT's staged reading of "Beneatha's Place" by Kwame Kwei-Armah on April 1st, 2015. From left: Bradleigh Watlington, Michael Baldwin, Meagan Mulgrew, Lucas Beecham, Kimberly Hicks)

To Show Our Appreciation...

  • For a $5 donation you will receive an email thank you!
  • For contributing $15 you will receive all $5 perks, plus a handwritten thank you note!
  • Donating $25 gets you all $15 perks, plus a video thank you from MAT!
  • Donating $50 gets you all $25 perks, plus a signed poster from the cast of our next production!
  • For a $100 donation you will receive all $50 perks, VIP seating of your choice at our next staged reading (email to set up), and a signed cast photo!


The Impact on Our Community

We seek to not only connect with our on-campus community, but to build a relationship with our local community by telling stories that reflect the diversity of Savannah, and open opportunities for discussion and collaboration. We invite you to connect with us and participate in our ongoing fundraising efforts, and we hope to see you in the audience!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute, but you can also help MAT in the following ways:

  • Join our mailing list and get notifications of performances by contacting us at matclub@scad.edu
  • Join us for our next staged reading, which will take place on Wednesday, May 27th at 5:30pm in the SCAD Museum Theater

(MAT's staged reading of "Beneatha's Place" by Kwame Kwei-Armah on April 1st, 2015. From left: Kimberly Hicks, Lucas Beecham, Meagan Mulgrew, Michael Baldwin, Bradleigh Watlington, Josh Bolla, DJames Jones, Kaitlyn Ortega, Lindsy Bissonnette)

story:
Last year Max in One Productions premiered it's first production, "The Music of Change", at the Aurora Fox Theater. We are following it up with "Women and Children First" in the same venue, and the funds are going towards advertising for the show.

The goal of Max in One productions is to get to a point where each show pays for the next. The logical way to accomplish that is to build a reliable audience, which requires that people see and are entertained by the show. And the way to ensure people see the show is by marketing the show. Marketing and advertising requires funds, and raising those funds is the purpose of this campaign.

The goal of expanding our audience is also reflected in the reward tiers. To raise the funds we need to properly market the show, we are essentially pre-selling tickets at a discount. The base tickets at the Aurora Fox box office will be $20; tickets pre-sold on this campaign will range from $15 to $10. This means that we get to grow our audience and raise the money we need to grow it even more with advertising, while simultaneously providing a 25-50% discount to those who contribute to our campaign.

"When I bought my ticket for the "The Music of Change" all I was really expecting was an evening out with my mom. What I actually got was an evening that hit a full spectrum of emotions from laughter to tears. I am so looking forward to the upcoming play to see how it will further change the way I see my own experiences." - Lauren Cordell

story:
Theater Reconstruction Ensemble is a newly formed New York based collective of theater artists striving to reconstruct both classical and contemporary experiments in theater through the playful development of works over time.  Committed to a collaborative approach to theater making, we function as an ensemble of actors, playwrights, designers, and directors working together to thoroughly examine each element of a theatrical text and collectively reconstruct the play in a personal and playful form, always paying homage to the original work while allowing ourselves to reinterpret and reinvent. After spending the past two and a half years making work with other companies, we’ve finally formed our own non-profit organization, and couldn’t be more excited to start producing bold reconstructions!

Our inaugural season kicks off February 2011 with a company launch party, featuring an exciting line-up of acts from company members, and friends and collaborators! Also planned for February 2011, as well as April and Summer 2011, are open rehearsals and workshop presentations of Chekhov’s THREE SISTERS and Marlowe’s DOCTOR FAUSTUS, two plays currently in development by the company. More info on these projects coming soon.

We are absolutely thrilled with the work we are making and cannot wait to share it with you all, but we will need your HELP to make our first season the best it can be! We are currently starting a full-fledged fundraising campaign to raise money for TRE’s first full-length production, a new staging of Ibsen's A DOLL’S HOUSE slated for April 2011 at The Access Theater Gallery in downtown Manhattan. As we continue to establish ourselves as a legitimate theater organization, we will have more work cut out for us than ever, and a serious need for financial support.

Here’s where you come in. We have until February __ to meet our initial target of $3,000. This money will be used for various production needs (space rentals, set, costumes, lights, transportation, etc) as well as basic company needs (insurance, fiscal sponsorship, website costs, marketing and personnel expenses, etc). 

With your help we can develop a beautiful and exciting season of works, and mount an explosive and inspired new production of A DOLL’S HOUSE. But it is only with your help that we can achieve these goals. A little bit really does go a long way. If each company member were to reach out to forty people for support, and if each of those forty people were to donate ten dollars, we would meet our goal. It truly is that simple. Donate more, donate less – every donation brings us one step closer to meeting our project goal. We feel so lucky to have people like you in our lives who have already supported us individually or collectively, and who continue to support our work.

This is an exciting and dangerous time to be starting up a new downtown experimental theater company. With the recent demise of so many cherished and beloved theater companies and venues in New York City, it has become increasingly more difficult and also increasingly more essential for young theater artists to explore and develop their own works over time. Your help in the beginning is crucial. We know that what we have as an ensemble of artists is special and unique, and it’s through your early donations that this ensemble will be given the opportunity to grow and create.

And best of all your gift is tax-deductible through our fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas, a 501(c)3 charity. We also have some great perks set up!

So make a donation, visit our website at www.reconstructionensemble.org and watch our videos, check out our photos, follow us on twitter and facebook. We are excited to welcome you to our family of supporters and collaborators!

Whatever you can donate, even if it is only your continued enthusiasm and support, we are so grateful. This season is already dedicated to all of you.

Thank you.

Much love,

John Kurzynowski, Artistic Director

Kate Marvin, Associate Artistic Director

Sydney Matthews, Producing Manager

Jaclyn Backhaus, Pete Forester, Stacy Jordan, Anastasia Olowin, Miguel Pinzon, Ensemble

story:
Our Story

URBAN CURVZ THEATRE was founded in 2005 with the goal of creating more professional productions in Calgary. Aberta that could provide female artists, both emerging and established, with engaging artistic opportunities.


In 2012 we are producing Hunger Striking by Kit Brennan,

running at the Pumphouse Theatre April 26 - May 5.


When one of Sarah's students dies of anorexia, Sarah is propelled into her own memories, taking her from her present day reality as a high school English teacher into multiple pasts: her own past as an anorexic girl twenty years earlier, her Celtic heritage with its vivid creatures and mythology passed on to her by her father, and the world of the hunger-striking suffragettes at the beginning of the last century. Though the battleground may be different, Sarah’s struggle to reconcile with herself is unnervingly easy to identify with.



The Impact

Hunger Striking asks the question: When your past actions resurface with a vengeance, can you forgive yourself and find compassion for your frailty?

 

This haunting and powerful production combines movement and story to take you into an altered world and deliver an experience that goes beyond the walls of logic, deep into the pulse of the body.

 

Working in partnership with the Calgary Region Mental Health Association, Urban Curvz is proud to present a story that explores the complex relationship between our bodies and our minds.

What We Need & What You Get

The money we seek to raise will go directly to paying the artists involved in the project. Your donation will help to sustain the future of our company.


Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you can contribute financially or not, please help us to spread the word! You can share us on Facebook, Tweet about us or forward this campaign to others you think might be interested in contributing or attending the production this spring. 

 

You can also attend our annual fundraising celebration, Curvilicious on March 19th. For more information and to keep up to date on all of our upcoming activities, visit our website or like our page on facebook.

 

www.urbancurvz.com

 

Find Us on Facebook! https://www.facebook.com/pages/Urban-Curvz-Thea...
